title: COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind
abstract: Theory of mind (ToM) refers to humans’ ability to understand and infer the desires, beliefs, and intentions of others. The acquisition of ToM plays a key role in humans’ social cognition and interpersonal relations. Though indispensable for social intelligence, ToM is still lacking for modern AI and NLP systems since they cannot access the human mental state and cognitive process beneath the training corpus. To empower AI systems with the ToM ability and narrow the gap between them and humans, in this paper, we propose COKE: the first cognitive knowledge graph for machine theory of mind. Specifically, COKE formalizes ToM as a collection of 45k+ manually verified cognitive chains that characterize human mental activities and subsequent behavioral/affective responses when facing specific social circumstances. In addition, we further generalize COKE using LLMs and build a powerful generation model COLM tailored for cognitive reasoning. Experimental results in both automatic and human evaluation demonstrate the high quality of COKE, the superior ToM ability of COLM, and its potential to significantly enhance social applications.
question: लेखक अपने प्रस्तावित मॉडल की तुलना में बेसलाइन के रूप में किन तीन मॉडल परिवारों का उपयोग करते हैं?
prompt: "COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Wu,Jincenzi et al. द्वारा, लेखक अपने प्रस्तावित मॉडल की तुलना में बेसलाइन के रूप में किन तीन मॉडल परिवारों का उपयोग करते हैं?
output_text: According to the paper "COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind" by Wu, Jincenzi et al., the authors use three baseline model families for comparison with their proposed model. These model families are:1. **Graph-based models**: These models represent knowledge graphs as a collection of nodes and edges, where nodes represent entities and edges represent relationships between them. The authors use graph-based models as a baseline to evaluate the performance of their proposed COKE model in representing cognitive knowledge graphs.2. **Attention-based models**: These models use attention mechanisms to focus on specific parts of the input data that are relevant for the task at hand. The authors use attention-based models as a baseline to evaluate the ability of their COKE model to selectively focus on relevant information in the cognitive knowledge graph.3. **Memory-augmented models**: These models incorporate external memory components to store and retrieve information, allowing them to learn and reason about complex knowledge graphs. The authors use memory-augmented models as a baseline to evaluate the ability of their COKE model to learn and reason about cognitive knowledge graphs.By comparing their proposed COKE model with these baseline model families, the authors aim to demonstrate the effectiveness of their approach in representing cognitive knowledge graphs and performing machine theory of mind tasks.

title: UnNatural Language Inference
abstract: Recent investigations into the inner-workings of state-of-the-art large-scale pre-trained Transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models indicate that they appear to understand human-like syntax, at least to some extent. We provide novel evidence that complicates this claim: we find that state-of-the-art Natural Language Inference (NLI) models assign the same labels to permuted examples as they do to the original, i.e. they are invariant to random word-order permutations. This behavior notably differs from that of humans; we struggle to understand the meaning of ungrammatical sentences. To measure the severity of this issue, we propose a suite of metrics and investigate which properties of particular permutations lead models to be word order invariant. For example, in MNLI dataset we find almost all (98.7%) examples contain at least one permutation which elicits the gold label. Models are even able to assign gold labels to permutations that they originally failed to predict correctly. We provide a comprehensive empirical evaluation of this phenomenon, and further show that this issue exists in pre-Transformer RNN / ConvNet based encoders, as well as across multiple languages (English and Chinese). Our code and data are available at https://github.com/facebookresearch/unlu.
question: शोध पत्र के निष्कर्ष के अनुसार, मैनिंग NLP समुदाय को क्या करने के लिए प्रोत्साहित करते हैं?
prompt: "UnNatural Language Inference" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Sinha,Koustuv et al. द्वारा, शोध पत्र के निष्कर्ष के अनुसार, मैनिंग NLP समुदाय को क्या करने के लिए प्रोत्साहित करते हैं?
output_text: The paper "UnNatural Language Inference" by Sinha, Koustuv et al. presents research findings that encourage the NLP community to focus on the following aspects:1. **Improved understanding of language**: The study highlights the limitations of current NLP models in understanding language nuances, particularly in the context of natural language inference (NLI). This emphasizes the need for more comprehensive and accurate language understanding capabilities in NLP systems.2. **Development of more robust NLI models**: The paper's findings suggest that current NLI models are prone to errors and biases, which underscores the importance of developing more robust and reliable NLI models that can accurately capture the complexities of human language.3. **Investigation of linguistic and cognitive factors**: The study's results indicate that linguistic and cognitive factors play a significant role in NLI. This encourages further research into these factors to better understand their impact on NLI and to develop more effective NLP models that can account for these factors.4. **Addressing the limitations of current evaluation metrics**: The paper highlights the limitations of current evaluation metrics for NLI tasks, which suggests the need for more comprehensive and nuanced evaluation metrics that can accurately assess the performance of NLI models.5. **Exploration of multimodal and multilingual NLI**: The study's findings also encourage the exploration of multimodal and multilingual NLI, which can lead to more comprehensive and effective NLP systems that can handle diverse linguistic and cognitive contexts.By addressing these aspects, the NLP community can work towards developing more accurate, robust, and human-like language understanding capabilities, ultimately leading to more effective and practical applications of NLP in various domains.

title: ESRA: Explainable Scientific Research Assistant
abstract: We introduce Explainable Scientific Research Assistant (ESRA), a literature discovery platform that augments search results with relevant details and explanations, aiding users in understanding more about their queries and the returned papers beyond existing literature search systems. Enabled by a knowledge graph we extracted from abstracts of 23k papers on the arXiv’s cs.CL category, ESRA provides three main features: explanation (for why a paper is returned to the user), list of facts (that are relevant to the query), and graph visualization (drawing connections between the query and each paper with surrounding related entities). The experimental results with humans involved show that ESRA can accelerate the users’ search process with paper explanations and helps them better explore the landscape of the topics of interest by exploiting the underlying knowledge graph. We provide the ESRA web application at http://esra.cp.eng.chula.ac.th/.
question: ऐसे कौन से दो फीचर हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैं लेकिन ESRA में हैं?
prompt: "ESRA: Explainable Scientific Research Assistant" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Hongwimol,Pollawat et al. द्वारा, ऐसे कौन से दो फीचर हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैं लेकिन ESRA में हैं?
output_text: ESRA: Explainable Scientific Research Assistant के लेख में Hongwimol, Pollawat et al. द्वारा उल्लेखित दो विशिष्ट विशेषताएं हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैं लेकिन ESRA में हैंः1. **Explainable AI (XAI) Integration**: ESRA में एकीकरण किया गया है Explainable AI (XAI) जो उपयोगकर्ताओं को AI के निर्णयों के पीछे की व्याख्या प्रदान करता है। यह विशेषता अन्य प्लेटफॉर्मों में अक्सर नहीं होती है, जो अक्सर AI के निर्णयों को स्पष्ट रूप से समझने के लिए आवश्यक होती है।2. **Multimodal Interaction**: ESRA में एक विशेषता है Multimodal Interaction जो उपयोगकर्ताओं को विभिन्न प्रकार के इनपुट के माध्यम से अनुसंधान सहायक के साथ संवाद करने की अनुमति देती है। यह विशेषता अन्य प्लेटफॉर्मों में अक्सर नहीं होती है, जो अक्सर एक ही प्रकार के इनपुट को स्वीकार करते हैं।ये विशेषताएं ESRA को अन्य प्लेटफॉर्मों से अलग करती हैं और इसे एक अद्वितीय अनुसंधान सहायक बनाती हैं।

title: How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?
abstract: This position paper describes and critiques the Pretraining-Agnostic Identically Distributed (PAID) evaluation paradigm, which has become a central tool for measuring progress in natural language understanding. This paradigm consists of three stages: (1) pre-training of a word prediction model on a corpus of arbitrary size; (2) fine-tuning (transfer learning) on a training set representing a classification task; (3) evaluation on a test set drawn from the same distribution as that training set. This paradigm favors simple, low-bias architectures, which, first, can be scaled to process vast amounts of data, and second, can capture the fine-grained statistical properties of a particular data set, regardless of whether those properties are likely to generalize to examples of the task outside the data set. This contrasts with humans, who learn language from several orders of magnitude less data than the systems favored by this evaluation paradigm, and generalize to new tasks in a consistent way. We advocate for supplementing or replacing PAID with paradigms that reward architectures that generalize as quickly and robustly as humans.
question: लेखक Test-only benchmarks के बारे में क्या कहते हैं?
prompt: "How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Linzen,Tal  द्वारा, लेखक Test-only benchmarks के बारे में क्या कहते हैं?
output_text: The article "How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?" by Linzen, Tal discusses the concept of test-only benchmarks in the context of natural language processing (NLP). According to the author, test-only benchmarks are a type of evaluation metric that assess the performance of a language model solely based on its ability to generalize to unseen test data, without considering its ability to learn from training data.In other words, test-only benchmarks evaluate a model's ability to perform well on a specific task or set of tasks without considering how it learned to perform those tasks. This approach is in contrast to traditional evaluation metrics, which often consider both the model's performance on test data and its ability to learn from training data.The author argues that test-only benchmarks are particularly useful for evaluating the ability of language models to generalize to unseen data, which is a critical aspect of human-like linguistic generalization. By evaluating a model's performance solely based on its ability to generalize to unseen data, test-only benchmarks provide a more direct measure of the model's ability to adapt to new and unfamiliar linguistic contexts.Overall, the article highlights the importance of test-only benchmarks in evaluating the ability of language models to generalize to unseen data, and argues that this approach can provide a more comprehensive understanding of a model's linguistic abilities.

title: Multi-Source Neural Machine Translation with Data Augmentation
abstract: Multi-source translation systems translate from multiple languages to a single target language. By using information from these multiple sources, these systems achieve large gains in accuracy. To train these systems, it is necessary to have corpora with parallel text in multiple sources and the target language. However, these corpora are rarely complete in practice due to the difficulty of providing human translations in all of the relevant languages. In this paper, we propose a data augmentation approach to fill such incomplete parts using multi-source neural machine translation (NMT). In our experiments, results varied over different language combinations but significant gains were observed when using a source language similar to the target language.

title: Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse
question: किसी वाक्य का centers क्या होता है?
prompt: "Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Grosz,Barbara J. et al. द्वारा, किसी वाक्य का centers क्या होता है?
output_text: A great question about a seminal paper in computational linguistics!In the paper "Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse" by Barbara J. Grosz, Scott D. Luperfoy, and Sandra K. Sidner, the authors introduce the concept of "centers" to model the local coherence of discourse. In essence, a center is a concept or entity that is the focus of attention in a discourse, and the authors propose that the coherence of a discourse can be understood by analyzing how the centers of attention are established, maintained, and shifted throughout the discourse.In more detail, a center is a concept that is introduced in a discourse and is the primary topic of discussion or the focus of attention. The authors argue that the coherence of a discourse can be understood by analyzing how the centers of attention are established, maintained, and shifted throughout the discourse. For example, in a conversation about a trip to the beach, the beach itself might be the center of attention at the beginning, but as the conversation progresses, the focus might shift to the activities that can be done at the beach, such as swimming or building sandcastles.The authors propose that there are three types of centers: the "current center," which is the focus of attention at a given moment; the "previous center," which was the focus of attention in the previous utterance; and the "next center," which is the focus of attention in the next utterance. By analyzing how these centers are established and shifted, the authors argue that we can better understand the coherence of a discourse and how it is maintained or disrupted.Overall, the concept of centers provides a framework for understanding how discourse is structured and how meaning is conveyed through the establishment and maintenance of a focus of attention.

title: Word Representations: A Simple and General Method for Semi-Supervised Learning
question: ब्राउन एल्गोरिदम पर आधारित क्लास बिग्राम भाषा मॉडल की कम्प्यूटेशनल जटिलता क्या है?
prompt: "Word Representations: A Simple and General Method for Semi-Supervised Learning" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Turian,Joseph et al. द्वारा, ब्राउन एल्गोरिदम पर आधारित क्लास बिग्राम भाषा मॉडल की कम्प्यूटेशनल जटिलता क्या है?
output_text: The paper "Word Representations: A Simple and General Method for Semi-Supervised Learning" by Turian, Joseph et al. presents a method for learning word representations using a combination of a Brown clustering algorithm and a neural network. The computational complexity of this method is not explicitly stated in the paper. However, we can break down the components of the method to estimate the computational complexity.1. Brown Clustering Algorithm: The Brown clustering algorithm is a simple and efficient method for clustering words based on their co-occurrence patterns. The computational complexity of the Brown clustering algorithm is O(n log n), where n is the number of words in the vocabulary.2. Neural Network: The neural network used in the method is a simple feedforward network with a single hidden layer. The computational complexity of the neural network is O(mn), where m is the number of neurons in the hidden layer and n is the number of words in the vocabulary.3. Word Representation Learning: The word representation learning process involves computing the word representations using the Brown clustering algorithm and the neural network. The computational complexity of this process is O(n log n) for the Brown clustering algorithm and O(mn) for the neural network.Overall, the computational complexity of the method is O(n log n) + O(mn), which simplifies to O(n log n) when m is a constant. Therefore, the computational complexity of the method is linear in the number of words in the vocabulary.It's worth noting that the computational complexity of the method can be further improved by using more efficient algorithms for the Brown clustering algorithm and the neural network. Additionally, the method can be parallelized to take advantage of multi-core processors and distributed computing architectures.

title: CNM: An Interpretable Complex-valued Network for Matching
abstract: This paper seeks to model human language by the mathematical framework of quantum physics. With the well-designed mathematical formulations in quantum physics, this framework unifies different linguistic units in a single complex-valued vector space, e.g. words as particles in quantum states and sentences as mixed systems. A complex-valued network is built to implement this framework for semantic matching. With well-constrained complex-valued components, the network admits interpretations to explicit physical meanings. The proposed complex-valued network for matching (CNM) achieves comparable performances to strong CNN and RNN baselines on two benchmarking question answering (QA) datasets.

With the well-designed mathematical formulations in quantum physics, this framework un
output_text: The research paper "CNM: An Interpretable Complex-valued Network for Matching" by Li, Qiuchi et al. studies the following datasets:1. **20 Newsgroups**: This dataset is a collection of approximately 20,000 newsgroup documents, evenly split across 20 different newsgroups. Each newsgroup represents a different topic, and the dataset is often used for text classification and topic modeling tasks.2. **IMDB**: The Internet Movie Database (IMDB) dataset is a collection of movie reviews, with each review labeled as either positive or negative. The dataset is commonly used for sentiment analysis and text classification tasks.3. **Stanford Sentiment Treebank**: This dataset is a collection of movie reviews from IMDB, with each review labeled as positive, negative, or neutral. The dataset is annotated with sentiment labels at the sentence and phrase levels, making it suitable for sentiment analysis and text classification tasks.These datasets are used to evaluate the performance of the proposed Complex-valued Network Model (CNM) in modeling human language using the mathematical framework of quantum physics.

title: CommonsenseQA: A Question Answering Challenge Targeting Commonsense Knowledge
abstract: When answering a question, people often draw upon their rich world knowledge in addition to the particular context. Recent work has focused primarily on answering questions given some relevant document or context, and required very little general background. To investigate question answering with prior knowledge, we present CommonsenseQA: a challenging new dataset for commonsense question answering. To capture common sense beyond associations, we extract from ConceptNet (Speer et al., 2017) multiple target concepts that have the same semantic relation to a single source concept. Crowd-workers are asked to author multiple-choice questions that mention the source concept and discriminate in turn between each of the target concepts. This encourages workers to create questions with complex semantics that often require prior knowledge. We create 12,247 questions through this procedure and demonstrate the difficulty of our task with a large number of strong baselines. Our best baseline is based on BERT-large (Devlin et al., 2018) and obtains 56% accuracy, well below human performance, which is 89%.

title: Probing the Need for Visual Context in Multimodal Machine Translation
abstract: Current work on multimodal machine translation (MMT) has suggested that the visual modality is either unnecessary or only marginally beneficial. We posit that this is a consequence of the very simple, short and repetitive sentences used in the only available dataset for the task (Multi30K), rendering the source text sufficient as context. In the general case, however, we believe that it is possible to combine visual and textual information in order to ground translations. In this paper we probe the contribution of the visual modality to state-of-the-art MMT models by conducting a systematic analysis where we partially deprive the models from source-side textual context. Our results show that under limited textual context, models are capable of leveraging the visual input to generate better translations. This contradicts the current belief that MMT models disregard the visual modality because of either the quality of the image features or the way they are integrated into the model.

We posit that this is a conseque
output_text: The research paper "Probing the Need for Visual Context in Multimodal Machine Translation" by Caglayan, Ozan et al. suggests that the visual modality is either unnecessary or only marginally beneficial in multimodal machine translation (MMT). This implies that the paper supports the idea that the visual context is not a crucial factor in MMT, and that the translation process can be effective without it.

title: BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding
abstract: We introduce a new language representation model called BERT, which stands for Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers. Unlike recent language representation models (Peters et al., 2018a; Radford et al., 2018), BERT is designed to pre-train deep bidirectional representations from unlabeled text by jointly conditioning on both left and right context in all layers. As a result, the pre-trained BERT model can be fine-tuned with just one additional output layer to create state-of-the-art models for a wide range of tasks, such as question answering and language inference, without substantial task-specific architecture modifications. BERT is conceptually simple and empirically powerful. It obtains new state-of-the-art results on eleven natural language processing tasks, including pushing the GLUE score to 80.5 (7.7 point absolute improvement), MultiNLI accuracy to 86.7% (4.6% absolute improvement), SQuAD v1.1 question answering Test F1 to 93.2 (1.5 point absolute improvement) and SQuAD v2.0 Test F1 to 83.1 (5.1 point absolute improvement).
question: प्री-ट्रेनेड लैंग्वेज रिप्रजेंटेशन को डाउनस्ट्रीम कार्यों पर लागू करने के लिए कौन-सी दो रणनीतियाँ इस्तेमाल की गयी  है?
prompt: "BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Devlin,Jacob et al. द्वारा, प्री-ट्रेनेड लैंग्वेज रिप्रजेंटेशन को डाउनस्ट्रीम कार्यों पर लागू करने के लिए कौन-सी दो रणनीतियाँ इस्तेमाल की गयी  है? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: We introduce a new language representation model called BERT, which stands for Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers. Unlike recent language representation mod
output_text: The two strategies used to apply pre-trained language representations to downstream tasks in the paper "BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding" by Devlin, Jacob et al. are:1. **Fine-tuning**: This involves training the pre-trained language representation model on the specific downstream task, while freezing the pre-trained weights. This approach allows the model to adapt to the specific task while retaining the general knowledge learned during pre-training.2. **Task-specific architectures**: This involves using the pre-trained language representation model as a feature extractor, and then adding a task-specific architecture on top of it. This approach allows the model to leverage the pre-trained language representation while still being tailored to the specific task.These strategies are used to leverage the pre-trained language representation model, BERT, for various downstream NLP tasks, such as question answering, sentiment analysis, and named entity recognition, among others.

title: What’s in a Name? Reducing Bias in Bios without Access to Protected Attributes
abstract: There is a growing body of work that proposes methods for mitigating bias in machine learning systems. These methods typically rely on access to protected attributes such as race, gender, or age. However, this raises two significant challenges: (1) protected attributes may not be available or it may not be legal to use them, and (2) it is often desirable to simultaneously consider multiple protected attributes, as well as their intersections. In the context of mitigating bias in occupation classification, we propose a method for discouraging correlation between the predicted probability of an individual’s true occupation and a word embedding of their name. This method leverages the societal biases that are encoded in word embeddings, eliminating the need for access to protected attributes. Crucially, it only requires access to individuals’ names at training time and not at deployment time. We evaluate two variations of our proposed method using a large-scale dataset of online biographies. We find that both variations simultaneously reduce race and gender biases, with almost no reduction in the classifier’s overall true positive rate.
question: नाम को दर्शाने के लिए कौन-सी वर्ड एम्बेडिंग विधि इस्तेमाल की गई है ?

These methods typically rely on access to protected attributes such as rac
output_text: The paper "What’s in a Name? Reducing Bias in Bios without Access to Protected Attributes" by Romanov, Alexey et al. uses the Word2Vec word embedding method to represent names.

title: Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics
question: शोध पत्र में प्रयुक्त percentage purity का सूत्र क्या है?
prompt: "Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Baroni,Marco et al. द्वारा, शोध पत्र में प्रयुक्त percentage purity का सूत्र क्या है?
output_text: The paper "Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics" by Baroni, Marco et al. uses the percentage purity metric to evaluate the quality of the learned representations. The formula for percentage purity is given as:Purity = (1 / N) * Σ |C_i ∩ C_j| / |C_i ∪ C_j|where:* N is the total number of clusters* C_i and C_j are two clusters* |C_i ∩ C_j| is the number of elements common to both clusters* |C_i ∪ C_j| is the total number of elements in both clustersThis formula calculates the purity of a cluster by comparing the number of elements that are common to the cluster and another cluster, to the total number of elements in both clusters. The purity score ranges from 0 to 1, where 1 indicates that all elements in the cluster belong to the same class, and 0 indicates that the cluster is randomly distributed across classes.

title: SemEval-2020 Task 4: Commonsense Validation and Explanation
abstract: In this paper, we present SemEval-2020 Task 4, Commonsense Validation and Explanation (ComVE), which includes three subtasks, aiming to evaluate whether a system can distinguish a natural language statement that makes sense to humans from one that does not, and provide the reasons. Specifically, in our first subtask, the participating systems are required to choose from two natural language statements of similar wording the one that makes sense and the one does not. The second subtask additionally asks a system to select the key reason from three options why a given statement does not make sense. In the third subtask, a participating system needs to generate the reason automatically. 39 teams submitted their valid systems to at least one subtask. For Subtask A and Subtask B, top-performing teams have achieved results closed to human performance. However, for Subtask C, there is still a considerable gap between system and human performance. The dataset used in our task can be found at https://github.com/wangcunxiang/SemEval2020-Task4-Commonsense-Validation-and-Explanation.
question: डेटा सेट में किन-किन प्रकार के वाक्य एकत्र किए गए हैं?
prompt: "SemEval-2020 Task 4: Commonsense Validation and Explanation" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Wang,Cunxiang et al. द्वारा, डेटा सेट में किन-किन प्रकार के वाक्य एकत्र किए गए हैं? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: In this paper, we present SemEval-2020 Task 4, Commonsense Validation and Explanation (ComVE), which includes three subtasks, aiming to evaluate whether a system can distinguish
output_text: According to the paper "SemEval-2020 Task 4: Commonsense Validation and Explanation" by Wang, Cunxiang et al., the data set includes three types of sentences:1. **Valid sentences**: These are sentences that are true in the real world and require common sense to understand.2. **Invalid sentences**: These are sentences that are false in the real world and require common sense to recognize as false.3. **Neutral sentences**: These are sentences that are neither true nor false in the real world and require common sense to determine their validity.These sentences are used to evaluate a system's ability to distinguish between valid and invalid sentences, and to explain why a sentence is valid or invalid.

title: SemEval-2020 Task 11: Detection of Propaganda Techniques in News Articles
abstract: We present the results and the main findings of SemEval-2020 Task 11 on Detection of Propaganda Techniques in News Articles. The task featured two subtasks. Subtask SI is about Span Identification: given a plain-text document, spot the specific text fragments containing propaganda. Subtask TC is about Technique Classification: given a specific text fragment, in the context of a full document, determine the propaganda technique it uses, choosing from an inventory of 14 possible propaganda techniques. The task attracted a large number of participants: 250 teams signed up to participate and 44 made a submission on the test set. In this paper, we present the task, analyze the results, and discuss the system submissions and the methods they used. For both subtasks, the best systems used pre-trained Transformers and ensembles.

Here is a brief description that you can use as a reference:1. **Appeal to Authority**: This technique involves citing an authority or expert to support a claim or argument.

title: PCC: Paraphrasing with Bottom-k Sampling and Cyclic Learning for Curriculum Data Augmentation
abstract: Curriculum Data Augmentation (CDA) improves neural models by presenting synthetic data with increasing difficulties from easy to hard. However, traditional CDA simply treats the ratio of word perturbation as the difficulty measure and goes through the curriculums only once. This paper presents PCC: Paraphrasing with Bottom-k Sampling and Cyclic Learning for Curriculum Data Augmentation, a novel CDA framework via paraphrasing, which exploits the textual paraphrase similarity as the curriculum difficulty measure. We propose a curriculum-aware paraphrase generation module composed of three units: a paraphrase candidate generator with bottom-k sampling, a filtering mechanism and a difficulty measure. We also propose a cyclic learning strategy that passes through the curriculums multiple times. The bottom-k sampling is proposed to generate super-hard instances for the later curriculums. Experimental results on few-shot text classification as well as dialogue generation indicate that PCC surpasses competitive baselines. Human evaluation and extensive case studies indicate that bottom-k sampling effectively generates super-hard instances, and PCC significantly improves the baseline dialogue agent.

The comparison suggests that PCC outperforms personaCHAT in terms of speed and efficiency. Specifically, PCC achieves better results in less time, indicating that it is faster than personaCHAT.

title: WinoDict: Probing language models for in-context word acquisition
abstract: We introduce a new in-context learning paradigm to measure Large Language Models’ (LLMs) ability to learn novel words during inference. In particular, we rewrite Winograd-style co-reference resolution problems by replacing the key concept word with a synthetic but plausible word that the model must understand to complete the task. Solving this task requires the model to make use of the dictionary definition of the new word given in the prompt. This benchmark addresses word acquisition, one important aspect of the diachronic degradation known to afflict LLMs. As LLMs are frozen in time at the moment they are trained, they are normally unable to reflect the way language changes over time. We show that the accuracy of LLMs compared to the original Winograd tasks decreases radically in our benchmark, thus identifying a limitation of current models and providing a benchmark to measure future improvements in LLMs ability to do in-context learning.

In particular, we rewrite Winograd-style

title: If beam search is the answer, what was the question?
abstract: Quite surprisingly, exact maximum a posteriori (MAP) decoding of neural language generators frequently leads to low-quality results. Rather, most state-of-the-art results on language generation tasks are attained using beam search despite its overwhelmingly high search error rate. This implies that the MAP objective alone does not express the properties we desire in text, which merits the question: if beam search is the answer, what was the question? We frame beam search as the exact solution to a different decoding objective in order to gain insights into why high probability under a model alone may not indicate adequacy. We find that beam search enforces uniform information density in text, a property motivated by cognitive science. We suggest a set of decoding objectives that explicitly enforce this property and find that exact decoding with these objectives alleviates the problems encountered when decoding poorly calibrated language generation models. Additionally, we analyze the text produced using various decoding strategies and see that, in our neural machine translation experiments, the extent to which this property is adhered to strongly correlates with BLEU.
question: यूनिफार्म इनफार्मेशन डेंसिटी परिकल्पना का वरणं करो |

Rather, most state-of-the-art results on lan
output_text: The paper "If beam search is the answer, what was the question?" by Meister, Clara et al. explores the concept of uniform information density (UID) hypothesis. The authors discuss how exact maximum a posteriori (MAP) decoding of neural language generators often results in low-quality outputs. Instead, they highlight that most state-of-the-art results in language generation tasks are achieved through the use of beam search, a heuristic search algorithm.

title: Media Framing: A typology and Survey of Computational Approaches Across Disciplines
abstract: Framing studies how individuals and societies make sense of the world, by communicating or representing complex issues through schema of interpretation. The framing of information in the mass media influences our interpretation of facts and corresponding decisions, so detecting and analysing it is essential to understand biases in the information we consume. Despite that, framing is still mostly examined manually, on a case-by-case basis, while existing large-scale automatic analyses using NLP methods are not mature enough to solve this task. In this survey we show that despite the growing interest to framing in NLP its current approaches do not capture those aspects which allow to frame, rather than simply convey, the message. To this end, we bring together definitions of frames and framing adopted in different disciplines; examine cognitive, linguistic, and communicative aspects a frame contains beyond its topical content. We survey recent work on computational frame detection, and discuss how framing aspects and frame definitions are (or should) be reflected in NLP approaches.

The framing of informati

title: COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind
abstract: Theory of mind (ToM) refers to humans’ ability to understand and infer the desires, beliefs, and intentions of others. The acquisition of ToM plays a key role in humans’ social cognition and interpersonal relations. Though indispensable for social intelligence, ToM is still lacking for modern AI and NLP systems since they cannot access the human mental state and cognitive process beneath the training corpus. To empower AI systems with the ToM ability and narrow the gap between them and humans, in this paper, we propose COKE: the first cognitive knowledge graph for machine theory of mind. Specifically, COKE formalizes ToM as a collection of 45k+ manually verified cognitive chains that characterize human mental activities and subsequent behavioral/affective responses when facing specific social circumstances. In addition, we further generalize COKE using LLMs and build a powerful generation model COLM tailored for cognitive reasoning. Experimental results in both automatic and human evaluation demonstrate the high quality of COKE, the superior ToM ability of COLM, and its potential to significantly enhance social applications.
question: लेखक अपने प्रस्तावित मॉडल की तुलना में बेसलाइन के रूप में किन तीन मॉडल परिवारों का उपयोग करते हैं?
prompt: "COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Wu,Jincenzi et al. द्वारा, लेखक अपने प्रस्तावित मॉडल की तुलना में बेसलाइन के रूप में किन तीन मॉडल परिवारों का उपयोग करते हैं? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: Theory of mind (ToM) refers to humans’ ability to understand and infer the desires, beliefs, and intentions of others. The acquisition of ToM plays a key role in humans’ social
output_text: According to the paper "COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind" by Wu, Jincenzi et al., the authors use three model families as baselines to compare their proposed model. These model families are:1. **Social Influence Models**: These models focus on understanding how individuals influence each other's beliefs and behaviors. They are based on the idea that people's actions are influenced by the actions and opinions of others.2. **Game-Theoretic Models**: These models analyze strategic decision-making in social situations, where individuals make choices based on their own preferences and the anticipated actions of others.3. **Cognitive Architectures**: These models aim to simulate human cognition, including attention, perception, and reasoning. They are designed to mimic human thought processes and decision-making.By comparing their proposed model, COKE, to these three model families, the authors aim to demonstrate its effectiveness in capturing the complexities of human social cognition and theory of mind.

title: UnNatural Language Inference
abstract: Recent investigations into the inner-workings of state-of-the-art large-scale pre-trained Transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models indicate that they appear to understand human-like syntax, at least to some extent. We provide novel evidence that complicates this claim: we find that state-of-the-art Natural Language Inference (NLI) models assign the same labels to permuted examples as they do to the original, i.e. they are invariant to random word-order permutations. This behavior notably differs from that of humans; we struggle to understand the meaning of ungrammatical sentences. To measure the severity of this issue, we propose a suite of metrics and investigate which properties of particular permutations lead models to be word order invariant. For example, in MNLI dataset we find almost all (98.7%) examples contain at least one permutation which elicits the gold label. Models are even able to assign gold labels to permutations that they originally failed to predict correctly. We provide a comprehensive empirical evaluation of this phenomenon, and further show that this issue exists in pre-Transformer RNN / ConvNet based encoders, as well as across multiple languages (English and Chinese). Our code and data are available at https://github.com/facebookresearch/unlu.
question: शोध पत्र के निष्कर्ष के अनुसार, मैनिंग NLP समुदाय को क्या करने के लिए प्रोत्साहित करते हैं?
prompt: "UnNatural Language Inference" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Sinha,Koustuv et al. द्वारा, शोध पत्र के निष्कर्ष के अनुसार, मैनिंग NLP समुदाय को क्या करने के लिए प्रोत्साहित करते हैं? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: Recent investigations into the inner-workings of state-of-the-art large-scale pre-trained Transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models indicate that they appear
output_text: According to the research paper "UnNatural Language Inference" by Sinha, Koustuv et al., the findings suggest that the NLP community should focus on understanding the limitations and biases of state-of-the-art large-scale pre-trained Transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models. The authors indicate that these models may not be as robust as previously thought, and may be prone to errors and biases due to their training data and architecture.Specifically, the paper highlights the need for further investigation into the following areas:1. **Understanding the limitations of pre-trained models**: The authors emphasize the importance of understanding the limitations of pre-trained models, including their potential biases and errors, to develop more robust and accurate NLU systems.2. **Investigating the role of training data**: The paper suggests that the training data used to pre-train these models may be biased or incomplete, leading to errors and biases in the models' performance.3. **Exploring alternative architectures and techniques**: The authors propose exploring alternative architectures and techniques to improve the robustness and accuracy of NLU models, potentially by incorporating domain-specific knowledge or using different training objectives.By acknowledging and addressing these limitations and biases, the NLP community can work towards developing more reliable and effective NLU models that better serve real-world applications.

title: ESRA: Explainable Scientific Research Assistant
abstract: We introduce Explainable Scientific Research Assistant (ESRA), a literature discovery platform that augments search results with relevant details and explanations, aiding users in understanding more about their queries and the returned papers beyond existing literature search systems. Enabled by a knowledge graph we extracted from abstracts of 23k papers on the arXiv’s cs.CL category, ESRA provides three main features: explanation (for why a paper is returned to the user), list of facts (that are relevant to the query), and graph visualization (drawing connections between the query and each paper with surrounding related entities). The experimental results with humans involved show that ESRA can accelerate the users’ search process with paper explanations and helps them better explore the landscape of the topics of interest by exploiting the underlying knowledge graph. We provide the ESRA web application at http://esra.cp.eng.chula.ac.th/.
question: ऐसे कौन से दो फीचर हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैं लेकिन ESRA में हैं?
prompt: "ESRA: Explainable Scientific Research Assistant" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Hongwimol,Pollawat et al. द्वारा, ऐसे कौन से दो फीचर हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैं लेकिन ESRA में हैं? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: We introduce Explainable Scientific Research Assistant (ESRA), a literature discovery platform that augments search results with relevant details and explanations, aiding users
output_text: ESRA में दो विशिष्ट विशेषताएं हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैंः1. **Search Results Augmentation**: ESRA का उपयोगकर्ताओं को लिटरेचर डिस्कवरी प्लेटफॉर्म के साथ साथ विस्तृत विवरण और व्याख्याएं प्रदान करता है, जिससे उपयोगकर्ताओं को उनके शोध के लिए अधिक सटीक और प्रासंगिक परिणाम प्राप्त करने में मदद मिलती है।2. **Explainable Search Results**: ESRA का एक अद्वितीय विशेषता है कि यह उपयोगकर्ताओं को उनके खोज परिणामों के पीछे की व्याख्या प्रदान करता है, जिससे उपयोगकर्ताओं को उनके शोध के परिणामों की गहराई से समझ में मदद मिलती है।

title: How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?
abstract: This position paper describes and critiques the Pretraining-Agnostic Identically Distributed (PAID) evaluation paradigm, which has become a central tool for measuring progress in natural language understanding. This paradigm consists of three stages: (1) pre-training of a word prediction model on a corpus of arbitrary size; (2) fine-tuning (transfer learning) on a training set representing a classification task; (3) evaluation on a test set drawn from the same distribution as that training set. This paradigm favors simple, low-bias architectures, which, first, can be scaled to process vast amounts of data, and second, can capture the fine-grained statistical properties of a particular data set, regardless of whether those properties are likely to generalize to examples of the task outside the data set. This contrasts with humans, who learn language from several orders of magnitude less data than the systems favored by this evaluation paradigm, and generalize to new tasks in a consistent way. We advocate for supplementing or replacing PAID with paradigms that reward architectures that generalize as quickly and robustly as humans.
question: लेखक Test-only benchmarks के बारे में क्या कहते हैं?
prompt: "How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Linzen,Tal  द्वारा, लेखक Test-only benchmarks के बारे में क्या कहते हैं? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: This position paper describes and critiques the Pretraining-Agnostic Identically Distributed (PAID) evaluation paradigm, which has become a central tool for measuring progress i
output_text: According to the paper "How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?" by Linzen, Tal, the author critiques the Pretraining-Agnostic Identically Distributed (PAID) evaluation paradigm, which has become a central tool for measuring progress in natural language processing (NLP) models. Specifically, the author argues that PAID benchmarks, which are designed to test a model's ability to generalize to unseen test data, are not sufficient for evaluating human-like linguistic generalization.The author suggests that PAID benchmarks are limited in their ability to capture the complexities of human language understanding and generation, as they often rely on simplistic and artificial test scenarios. Additionally, the author notes that PAID benchmarks may not be able to capture the nuances of human language use, such as context-dependent meaning and pragmatic inference.The author proposes alternative evaluation paradigms that focus on more realistic and complex language use, such as testing models on real-world texts or evaluating their ability to generate coherent and contextually appropriate responses. These alternative paradigms aim to better align with the way humans use and understand language, and to provide a more comprehensive assessment of a model's linguistic generalization abilities.

title: Multi-Source Neural Machine Translation with Data Augmentation
abstract: Multi-source translation systems translate from multiple languages to a single target language. By using information from these multiple sources, these systems achieve large gains in accuracy. To train these systems, it is necessary to have corpora with parallel text in multiple sources and the target language. However, these corpora are rarely complete in practice due to the difficulty of providing human translations in all of the relevant languages. In this paper, we propose a data augmentation approach to fill such incomplete parts using multi-source neural machine translation (NMT). In our experiments, results varied over different language combinations but significant gains were observed when using a source language similar to the target language.
question: कौन कौन से टारगेट भाषाएँ उपयोग की गयी है ?

output_text: According to the paper "Multi-Source Neural Machine Translation with Data Augmentation" by Nishimura, Yuta et al., the target language used in this study is English.

title: Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse
question: किसी वाक्य का centers क्या होता है?
prompt: "Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Grosz,Barbara J. et al. द्वारा, किसी वाक्य का centers क्या होता है?
output_text: A very interesting topic!In the paper "Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse" by Grosz, Barlas, and Sidner (1995), a "discourse center" refers to a concept in computational linguistics and artificial intelligence that helps establish coherence in human-computer communication. In essence, it is the entity (object, person, etc.) that the speaker is focusing on when making claims or statements.To elucidate, consider a sentence "John owns a car." In this scenario, "John" is the discourse center. The sentence establishes a connection between John and the fact that John owns a car. Now, if the speaker proceeds to talk about John owning a house, "John" is still the discourse center as the conversational thread remains connected to him. If however, the speaker starts discussing "houses on sale this week", "houses" could become the new discourse center as the conversation shifts to talk about the subject of "houses."Discourse center is thus a mechanism for modeling and tracking the focus of an utterance (i.e., the core idea being discussed) within a sequence of sentences in a coherent and relevant manner.

title: Word Representations: A Simple and General Method for Semi-Supervised Learning
question: ब्राउन एल्गोरिदम पर आधारित क्लास बिग्राम भाषा मॉडल की कम्प्यूटेशनल जटिलता क्या है?
prompt: "Word Representations: A Simple and General Method for Semi-Supervised Learning" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Turian,Joseph et al. द्वारा, ब्राउन एल्गोरिदम पर आधारित क्लास बिग्राम भाषा मॉडल की कम्प्यूटेशनल जटिलता क्या है?
output_text: The Brown clustering algorithm on which the Word Representations model, called Brown clustering algorithm, uses the k-means algorithm to cluster words based on their vocablulary to create a hierarchical clustering of the vocabulary. The k-means algorithm requires a fixed number of clusters to be specified in advance, and it does not provide a clear method for selecting the optimal number of clusters. That being said, the computational complexity time is O(nkm) and O(nk + np) where kn denotes the number of clusters, n denotes the total number of words, and p denotes the dimensionality.Here is a breakdown of the process involved and their computational complexity:1. Preprocessing of the text: This involves removing stop words, converting all text to lowercase, counting word frequencies, and removing the less frequent words. Computational complexity for this is directly proportional to the number of words in the vocabulary.2. Word Representation: A word is projected in a vector space through a k-neighborhood that captures the co-occurrence patterns with similar words. The computational complexity for this lies in counting of similar words' frequency for a given word, which in turn is dependent on the number of words and the co-occurrences required.3. Hierarchical Clustering: This involves the clustering of similar words together using k-means clustering algorithm which in itself involves computation of centroid for each cluster, and this has a computational complexity of O(nmk) where k is the number of clusters.Therefore, for clustering words using word representations which is a Brown clustering algorithm based method, the total computational complexity is a combination of preprocessing complexity, word representation complexity and hierarchical clustering complexity. The time required can therefore, depend on the size of the vocabulary, word frequencies, number of clusters for k-means clustering and the dimensionality of the word representation.

title: CNM: An Interpretable Complex-valued Network for Matching
abstract: This paper seeks to model human language by the mathematical framework of quantum physics. With the well-designed mathematical formulations in quantum physics, this framework unifies different linguistic units in a single complex-valued vector space, e.g. words as particles in quantum states and sentences as mixed systems. A complex-valued network is built to implement this framework for semantic matching. With well-constrained complex-valued components, the network admits interpretations to explicit physical meanings. The proposed complex-valued network for matching (CNM) achieves comparable performances to strong CNN and RNN baselines on two benchmarking question answering (QA) datasets.
question: कौन-कौन सा डेटासेट इस शोध पत्र में अध्ययन किया गया है?
prompt: "CNM: An Interpretable Complex-valued Network for Matching" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Li,Qiuchi et al. द्वारा, कौन-कौन सा डेटासेट इस शोध पत्र में अध्ययन किया गया है?
output_text: "CNM: An Interpretable Complex-valued Network for Matching" शीर्षक वाले शोध पत्र में, Li, Qiuchi द्वारा संयुक्त रूप से प्रदान किये गये डेटासेट का विशेष रूप से उल्लेख नहीं किया गया है। हालांकि, पत्र मौजूद होता है कि इस दशक में, काफी सारे अनुसंधान पत्रों में विभिन्न डेटासेट पर विविध विषयों पर काम किया गया है।इसके अलावा, पत्र वर्णन करता है कि सूचना मानचित्रण एक प्रमुख चुनौती है, विशेष रूप से ऐसी स्थितियों में जब डेटा की विविधता और जटिलता होती है। इस प्रक्रिया को सुलझाने के लिए, पत्र के लेखकों ने Complex-Valued Network (CNM) प्रस्तुत किया लेकिन डेटासेट की विवरणी रूप में नहीं की गई है।

title: CommonsenseQA: A Question Answering Challenge Targeting Commonsense Knowledge
abstract: When answering a question, people often draw upon their rich world knowledge in addition to the particular context. Recent work has focused primarily on answering questions given some relevant document or context, and required very little general background. To investigate question answering with prior knowledge, we present CommonsenseQA: a challenging new dataset for commonsense question answering. To capture common sense beyond associations, we extract from ConceptNet (Speer et al., 2017) multiple target concepts that have the same semantic relation to a single source concept. Crowd-workers are asked to author multiple-choice questions that mention the source concept and discriminate in turn between each of the target concepts. This encourages workers to create questions with complex semantics that often require prior knowledge. We create 12,247 questions through this procedure and demonstrate the difficulty of our task with a large number of strong baselines. Our best baseline is based on BERT-large (Devlin et al., 2018) and obtains 56% accuracy, well below human performance, which is 89%.
question: लेखकों द्वारा प्रस्तावित डेटा सेट में सबसे ज्यादा इस्तेमाल होने वाले शब्दों में दूसरा सबसे आम शब्द कौन सा है?
prompt: "CommonsenseQA: A Question Answering Challenge Targeting Commonsense Knowledge" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Talmor,Alon et al. द्वारा, लेखकों द्वारा प्रस्तावित डेटा सेट में सबसे ज्यादा इस्तेमाल होने वाले शब्दों में दूसरा सबसे आम शब्द कौन सा है?
output_text: CommonsenseQA लेख में, लेखकों Talmor, Alon et al. ने प्रस्तुत किए गए सबसे अधिक उपयोग किए जाने वाले शब्दों में दूसरा सबसे आम शब्द "knowledge" (ज्ञान) है।

title: Probing the Need for Visual Context in Multimodal Machine Translation
abstract: Current work on multimodal machine translation (MMT) has suggested that the visual modality is either unnecessary or only marginally beneficial. We posit that this is a consequence of the very simple, short and repetitive sentences used in the only available dataset for the task (Multi30K), rendering the source text sufficient as context. In the general case, however, we believe that it is possible to combine visual and textual information in order to ground translations. In this paper we probe the contribution of the visual modality to state-of-the-art MMT models by conducting a systematic analysis where we partially deprive the models from source-side textual context. Our results show that under limited textual context, models are capable of leveraging the visual input to generate better translations. This contradicts the current belief that MMT models disregard the visual modality because of either the quality of the image features or the way they are integrated into the model.
question: यह शोध पत्र जिस प्रभाव की प्रधानता दिखाता है, वह किस महत्वपूर्ण कार्य का समर्थन करता है?
prompt: "Probing the Need for Visual Context in Multimodal Machine Translation" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Caglayan,Ozan et al. द्वारा, यह शोध पत्र जिस प्रभाव की प्रधानता दिखाता है, वह किस महत्वपूर्ण कार्य का समर्थन करता है?
output_text: The research paper "Probing the Need for Visual Context in Multimodal Machine Translation" by Caglayan, Ozan et al. strongly emphasizes the significance of visual context in multimodal machine translation, implying that it provides crucial support to the vital effort of bridging the gap between visual and linguistic representations for accurate meaning interpretation. It highlights the importance of considering visual context in conjunction with the corresponding text to improve machine translation outcomes, thereby illustrating the significance of multimodal integration in capturing and translating the nuances of human communication effectively.

title: BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding
abstract: We introduce a new language representation model called BERT, which stands for Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers. Unlike recent language representation models (Peters et al., 2018a; Radford et al., 2018), BERT is designed to pre-train deep bidirectional representations from unlabeled text by jointly conditioning on both left and right context in all layers. As a result, the pre-trained BERT model can be fine-tuned with just one additional output layer to create state-of-the-art models for a wide range of tasks, such as question answering and language inference, without substantial task-specific architecture modifications. BERT is conceptually simple and empirically powerful. It obtains new state-of-the-art results on eleven natural language processing tasks, including pushing the GLUE score to 80.5 (7.7 point absolute improvement), MultiNLI accuracy to 86.7% (4.6% absolute improvement), SQuAD v1.1 question answering Test F1 to 93.2 (1.5 point absolute improvement) and SQuAD v2.0 Test F1 to 83.1 (5.1 point absolute improvement).
question: प्री-ट्रेनेड लैंग्वेज रिप्रजेंटेशन को डाउनस्ट्रीम कार्यों पर लागू करने के लिए कौन-सी दो रणनीतियाँ इस्तेमाल की गयी  है?
prompt: "BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Devlin,Jacob et al. द्वारा, प्री-ट्रेनेड लैंग्वेज रिप्रजेंटेशन को डाउनस्ट्रीम कार्यों पर लागू करने के लिए कौन-सी दो रणनीतियाँ इस्तेमाल की गयी  है?
output_text: The paper "BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding" by Devlin, Jacob et al. discusses pre-training a deep bidirectional transformer model for language understanding and applying it to downstream tasks. Two strategies were used to apply the pre-trained language representation to downstream tasks:1. **Task-specific layer on top**: In this approach, a task-specific layer was added on top of the pre-trained BERT model, along with a classifier or output layer specific to the downstream task. This task-specific layer is trained along with the other model parameters, and the pre-trained BERT model was used as fixed parameters. This approach was used for sentiment analysis, language translation, and question answering tasks.2. **Fine-tuning all parameters**: In this approach, the entire BERT model with all its layers was fine-tuned on a downstream task dataset. This was done by adding random noise to the pre-trained weights and training all the parameters simultaneously. This approach was found to work well for named entity recognition and other tasks.The authors demonstrated that the pre-training technique and fine-tuning strategies are effective for improving the performance of language understanding tasks, leading to state-of-the-art results in several benchmark datasets.

title: What’s in a Name? Reducing Bias in Bios without Access to Protected Attributes
abstract: There is a growing body of work that proposes methods for mitigating bias in machine learning systems. These methods typically rely on access to protected attributes such as race, gender, or age. However, this raises two significant challenges: (1) protected attributes may not be available or it may not be legal to use them, and (2) it is often desirable to simultaneously consider multiple protected attributes, as well as their intersections. In the context of mitigating bias in occupation classification, we propose a method for discouraging correlation between the predicted probability of an individual’s true occupation and a word embedding of their name. This method leverages the societal biases that are encoded in word embeddings, eliminating the need for access to protected attributes. Crucially, it only requires access to individuals’ names at training time and not at deployment time. We evaluate two variations of our proposed method using a large-scale dataset of online biographies. We find that both variations simultaneously reduce race and gender biases, with almost no reduction in the classifier’s overall true positive rate.
question: नाम को दर्शाने के लिए कौन-सी वर्ड एम्बेडिंग विधि इस्तेमाल की गई है ?
prompt: "What’s in a Name? Reducing Bias in Bios without Access to Protected Attributes" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Romanov,Alexey et al. द्वारा, नाम को दर्शाने के लिए कौन-सी वर्ड एम्बेडिंग विधि इस्तेमाल की गई है ?
output_text: According to the paper "What’s in a Name? Reducing Bias in Bios without Access to Protected Attributes" by Romanov, Alexey et al., a widely used method for word embedding in the context of names is Word2Vec. Specifically, they use the continuous skip-gram model and CBOW (Continuous Bag of Words) for their research.

title: Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics
question: शोध पत्र में प्रयुक्त percentage purity का सूत्र क्या है?
prompt: "Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Baroni,Marco et al. द्वारा, शोध पत्र में प्रयुक्त percentage purity का सूत्र क्या है?
output_text: The interesting question!According to the paper "Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics" by Baroni, et al., the percentage purity (P) is calculated as follows:P = |{i | ∀ x, y: φ(x,y) = f(tau_i) ∧ φ(x,z_i) \ne 0}|∑|{|{i | ∀ x: φ(x,y) = f(tau_i)}|}where- φ is the semantic mapping- t_i's are prototypical sentence representations- f(τ_i) is the semantic value of the i-th context, calculated as the average feature value of the context τ_i.- |.| denotes set size or cardinality- 1 ≤ i ≤ n represents the set of contextsIn simpler terms, P measures the extent to which a specific context is representative (pure) across different sentences in the corpus.The research paper "Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics" was published in Cognitive Science in 2014.

title: SemEval-2020 Task 4: Commonsense Validation and Explanation
abstract: In this paper, we present SemEval-2020 Task 4, Commonsense Validation and Explanation (ComVE), which includes three subtasks, aiming to evaluate whether a system can distinguish a natural language statement that makes sense to humans from one that does not, and provide the reasons. Specifically, in our first subtask, the participating systems are required to choose from two natural language statements of similar wording the one that makes sense and the one does not. The second subtask additionally asks a system to select the key reason from three options why a given statement does not make sense. In the third subtask, a participating system needs to generate the reason automatically. 39 teams submitted their valid systems to at least one subtask. For Subtask A and Subtask B, top-performing teams have achieved results closed to human performance. However, for Subtask C, there is still a considerable gap between system and human performance. The dataset used in our task can be found at https://github.com/wangcunxiang/SemEval2020-Task4-Commonsense-Validation-and-Explanation.
question: डेटा सेट में किन-किन प्रकार के वाक्य एकत्र किए गए हैं?
prompt: "SemEval-2020 Task 4: Commonsense Validation and Explanation" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Wang,Cunxiang et al. द्वारा, डेटा सेट में किन-किन प्रकार के वाक्य एकत्र किए गए हैं?
output_text: सемेवाल 2020 की चौथी द्वितीय प्रकार की कार्य नामक 'सामान्य ज्ञान की वैलिडेशन और समझ' पर उनका काम कर रहा है। इस कार्य के माध्यम से उन्होंने अपने डेटा सेट के एक महत्वपूर्ण हिस्से के रूप में वाल स्टोरी कथा डेटा संग्रह बनाया, जिन्हें अक्सर चित्रित कथा कहा जाता है। इन कथाओं में लगभग 30,000 ग्राफ हैं, कुल 1500 सौ उपन्यास वाले विजय की जीवन वृत्ति और पाठों का उपयोग करके गढ़े गए कथाओं। यह डेटसेट कहानी अन्वेषण का एक शक्तिशाली साधन बनने के काबिल है।

title: SemEval-2020 Task 11: Detection of Propaganda Techniques in News Articles
abstract: We present the results and the main findings of SemEval-2020 Task 11 on Detection of Propaganda Techniques in News Articles. The task featured two subtasks. Subtask SI is about Span Identification: given a plain-text document, spot the specific text fragments containing propaganda. Subtask TC is about Technique Classification: given a specific text fragment, in the context of a full document, determine the propaganda technique it uses, choosing from an inventory of 14 possible propaganda techniques. The task attracted a large number of participants: 250 teams signed up to participate and 44 made a submission on the test set. In this paper, we present the task, analyze the results, and discuss the system submissions and the methods they used. For both subtasks, the best systems used pre-trained Transformers and ensembles.
question: शेयर्ड टास्क  में उपयोग किए गए डेटा सेट में प्रयुक्त 14 विभिन्न प्रचार तकनीकों की सूची दो ।
