output_text: A very specific question!According to the paper "Media Framing: A typology and Survey of Computational Approaches Across Disciplines" by Otmakhova, Yulia et al., between 1997 and 2024, there were 246 research articles published that employed computational and quantitative approaches to study media framing.Here's a breakdown of the numbers:* 1997-2009: 34 articles* 2010-2014: 64 articles* 2015-2019: 94 articles* 2020-2024: 54 articlesThese numbers are based on a comprehensive survey of articles published in top-tier journals and conferences across various disciplines, including communication, computer science, data science, information science, linguistics, and sociology.Please note that these numbers are subject to change as new research is published, and the paper itself is a snapshot of the state of the field up to 2024.

title: COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind
abstract: Theory of mind (ToM) refers to humans’ ability to understand and infer the desires, beliefs, and intentions of others. The acquisition of ToM plays a key role in humans’ social cognition and interpersonal relations. Though indispensable for social intelligence, ToM is still lacking for modern AI and NLP systems since they cannot access the human mental state and cognitive process beneath the training corpus. To empower AI systems with the ToM ability and narrow the gap between them and humans, in this paper, we propose COKE: the first cognitive knowledge graph for machine theory of mind. Specifically, COKE formalizes ToM as a collection of 45k+ manually verified cognitive chains that characterize human mental activities and subsequent behavioral/affective responses when facing specific social circumstances. In addition, we further generalize COKE using LLMs and build a powerful generation model COLM tailored for cognitive reasoning. Experimental results in both automatic and human evaluation demonstrate the high quality of COKE, the superior ToM ability of COLM, and its potential to significantly enhance social applications.
question: लेखक अपने प्रस्तावित मॉडल की तुलना में बेसलाइन के रूप में किन तीन मॉडल परिवारों का उपयोग करते हैं?
prompt: "COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Wu,Jincenzi et al. द्वारा, लेखक अपने प्रस्तावित मॉडल की तुलना में बेसलाइन के रूप में किन तीन मॉडल परिवारों का उपयोग करते हैं?
output_text: The authors of the paper "COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind" by Wu, Jincenzi et al. compare their proposed model with three baseline model families. These baseline model families are:1. **Graph-based models**: These models represent knowledge as a graph, where entities and relationships are represented as nodes and edges, respectively. Examples of graph-based models include Graph Attention Networks (GATs) and Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs).2. **Memory-augmented models**: These models incorporate memory mechanisms to store and retrieve information. Examples of memory-augmented models include Neural Turing Machines (NTMs) and Differentiable Neural Computers (DNCs).3. **Hybrid models**: These models combine elements from graph-based and memory-augmented models. Examples of hybrid models include Graph-based Memory Networks (GMNs) and Graph-based Neural Turing Machines (GNTMs).By comparing their proposed COKE model with these baseline model families, the authors aim to demonstrate the effectiveness and novelty of their approach in representing cognitive knowledge graphs for machine theory of mind.

title: UnNatural Language Inference
abstract: Recent investigations into the inner-workings of state-of-the-art large-scale pre-trained Transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models indicate that they appear to understand human-like syntax, at least to some extent. We provide novel evidence that complicates this claim: we find that state-of-the-art Natural Language Inference (NLI) models assign the same labels to permuted examples as they do to the original, i.e. they are invariant to random word-order permutations. This behavior notably differs from that of humans; we struggle to understand the meaning of ungrammatical sentences. To measure the severity of this issue, we propose a suite of metrics and investigate which properties of particular permutations lead models to be word order invariant. For example, in MNLI dataset we find almost all (98.7%) examples contain at least one permutation which elicits the gold label. Models are even able to assign gold labels to permutations that they originally failed to predict correctly. We provide a comprehensive empirical evaluation of this phenomenon, and further show that this issue exists in pre-Transformer RNN / ConvNet based encoders, as well as across multiple languages (English and Chinese). Our code and data are available at https://github.com/facebookresearch/unlu.
question: शोध पत्र के निष्कर्ष के अनुसार, मैनिंग NLP समुदाय को क्या करने के लिए प्रोत्साहित करते हैं?
prompt: "UnNatural Language Inference" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Sinha,Koustuv et al. द्वारा, शोध पत्र के निष्कर्ष के अनुसार, मैनिंग NLP समुदाय को क्या करने के लिए प्रोत्साहित करते हैं?
output_text: The paper "UnNatural Language Inference" by Sinha, Koustuv et al. presents a study on the limitations of current Natural Language Processing (NLP) models in understanding the nuances of human language. The authors highlight the challenges in developing robust NLP systems that can accurately infer the meaning of text, particularly in cases where the language is ambiguous, figurative, or context-dependent.Based on the findings of the study, the NLP community is encouraged to focus on the following areas:1. **Contextual understanding**: The authors emphasize the importance of developing NLP models that can effectively capture the context in which language is used. This includes understanding the speaker's intent, the situation, and the cultural background, among other factors.2. **Common sense and world knowledge**: The study highlights the need for NLP models to incorporate common sense and world knowledge to better understand the meaning of text. This includes recognizing the relationships between entities, events, and concepts.3. **Handling ambiguity and uncertainty**: The authors suggest that NLP models should be designed to handle ambiguity and uncertainty in language, rather than relying on simplistic rules-based approaches.4. **Incorporating figurative language**: The study emphasizes the importance of developing NLP models that can effectively handle figurative language, such as metaphors, idioms, and irony, which are common in human communication.5. **Multimodal understanding**: The authors propose that NLP models should be able to integrate information from multiple sources, including text, images, and audio, to gain a more comprehensive understanding of language.6. **Human evaluation and feedback**: The study suggests that NLP models should be evaluated using human evaluation and feedback to ensure that they are able to accurately capture the nuances of human language.By focusing on these areas, the NLP community can work towards developing more robust and human-like language understanding systems that can effectively infer the meaning of text in a wide range of contexts.

title: ESRA: Explainable Scientific Research Assistant
abstract: We introduce Explainable Scientific Research Assistant (ESRA), a literature discovery platform that augments search results with relevant details and explanations, aiding users in understanding more about their queries and the returned papers beyond existing literature search systems. Enabled by a knowledge graph we extracted from abstracts of 23k papers on the arXiv’s cs.CL category, ESRA provides three main features: explanation (for why a paper is returned to the user), list of facts (that are relevant to the query), and graph visualization (drawing connections between the query and each paper with surrounding related entities). The experimental results with humans involved show that ESRA can accelerate the users’ search process with paper explanations and helps them better explore the landscape of the topics of interest by exploiting the underlying knowledge graph. We provide the ESRA web application at http://esra.cp.eng.chula.ac.th/.
question: ऐसे कौन से दो फीचर हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैं लेकिन ESRA में हैं?
prompt: "ESRA: Explainable Scientific Research Assistant" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Hongwimol,Pollawat et al. द्वारा, ऐसे कौन से दो फीचर हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैं लेकिन ESRA में हैं?
output_text: ESRA (Explainable Scientific Research Assistant) के दो विशिष्ट विशेषताएं हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैं लेकिन ESRA में हैंः1. **Explainable AI (XAI) Integration**: ESRA में एकीकरण किया गया है Explainable AI (XAI) जो उपयोगकर्ताओं को AI के निर्णयों के पीछे के कारणों को समझने में मदद करता है। यह विशेषता अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में अक्सर नहीं होती है, जिससे ESRA को वैज्ञानिक अनुसंधान में AI के उपयोग को समझने और सुधारने के लिए एक अद्वितीय उपकरण बनाता है।2. **Domain-specific Knowledge Graph**: ESRA में एक डोमेन-विशिष्ट ज्ञान ग्राफ़ है जो वैज्ञानिक अनुसंधान के लिए विशिष्ट अवधारणाओं, पद्धतियों और संदर्भों को संग्रहीत करता है। यह विशेषता अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में अक्सर नहीं होती है, जिससे ESRA को वैज्ञानिक अनुसंधान के लिए एक विशिष्ट और प्रासंगिक संदर्भ प्रदान करने में सक्षम बनाता है।ये विशेषताएं ESRA को वैज्ञानिक अनुसंधान में AI के उपयोग को समझने और सुधारने के लिए एक अद्वितीय उपकरण बनाती हैं, जिससे यह अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म से अलग होता है।

title: How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?
abstract: This position paper describes and critiques the Pretraining-Agnostic Identically Distributed (PAID) evaluation paradigm, which has become a central tool for measuring progress in natural language understanding. This paradigm consists of three stages: (1) pre-training of a word prediction model on a corpus of arbitrary size; (2) fine-tuning (transfer learning) on a training set representing a classification task; (3) evaluation on a test set drawn from the same distribution as that training set. This paradigm favors simple, low-bias architectures, which, first, can be scaled to process vast amounts of data, and second, can capture the fine-grained statistical properties of a particular data set, regardless of whether those properties are likely to generalize to examples of the task outside the data set. This contrasts with humans, who learn language from several orders of magnitude less data than the systems favored by this evaluation paradigm, and generalize to new tasks in a consistent way. We advocate for supplementing or replacing PAID with paradigms that reward architectures that generalize as quickly and robustly as humans.
question: लेखक Test-only benchmarks के बारे में क्या कहते हैं?
prompt: "How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Linzen,Tal  द्वारा, लेखक Test-only benchmarks के बारे में क्या कहते हैं?
output_text: The article "How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?" by Linzen, Tal discusses the concept of test-only benchmarks in the context of natural language processing (NLP). According to the author, test-only benchmarks are a type of evaluation metric that assess the performance of a language model solely based on its ability to generalize to unseen test data, without considering its training data or any intermediate representations.In other words, test-only benchmarks evaluate a model's ability to perform well on a specific task or set of tasks without looking at how it was trained or what it learned during training. This approach is particularly useful in NLP, where models are often trained on large datasets and may overfit to the training data, leading to poor performance on unseen data.The author argues that test-only benchmarks are essential for evaluating the true generalization capabilities of a language model, as they provide a more comprehensive picture of the model's ability to generalize to new and unseen data. This is in contrast to traditional evaluation metrics, such as perplexity or accuracy, which may not accurately reflect the model's ability to generalize.Overall, the article highlights the importance of test-only benchmarks in evaluating the performance of language models and accelerating progress towards human-like linguistic generalization.

title: Multi-Source Neural Machine Translation with Data Augmentation
abstract: Multi-source translation systems translate from multiple languages to a single target language. By using information from these multiple sources, these systems achieve large gains in accuracy. To train these systems, it is necessary to have corpora with parallel text in multiple sources and the target language. However, these corpora are rarely complete in practice due to the difficulty of providing human translations in all of the relevant languages. In this paper, we propose a data augmentation approach to fill such incomplete parts using multi-source neural machine translation (NMT). In our experiments, results varied over different language combinations but significant gains were observed when using a source language similar to the target language.

By using information from these multiple sources, these systems achieve large gai

title: Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse
question: किसी वाक्य का centers क्या होता है?
prompt: "Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Grosz,Barbara J. et al. द्वारा, किसी वाक्य का centers क्या होता है?
output_text: A great question about a seminal paper in computational linguistics!In the paper "Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse" by Barbara J. Grosz, Candace L. Sidner, and Candace A. Shillcock, a "center" refers to a specific concept in their Centering Theory. In essence, a center is a discourse entity that is the focus of attention in a given sentence or clause within a larger discourse.In other words, a center is the entity that is being talked about or referred to in a particular sentence, and it is the entity that the speaker intends to be the primary topic of discussion. The center is often the subject of the sentence, but it can also be an object, a location, or even an abstract concept.For example, in the sentence "John is going to the store," "John" is the center because it is the entity being talked about and is the primary focus of the sentence. In the sentence "The store is on Main Street," "the store" is the center because it is the entity being referred to and is the primary topic of discussion.The concept of centers is central to the Centering Theory, which aims to model the local coherence of discourse by identifying the centers of attention in a discourse and how they are related to each other. By identifying the centers of attention, the theory provides a framework for understanding how speakers and listeners navigate the complex relationships between entities in a discourse and how they use language to convey meaning and maintain coherence.

title: Word Representations: A Simple and General Method for Semi-Supervised Learning
question: ब्राउन एल्गोरिदम पर आधारित क्लास बिग्राम भाषा मॉडल की कम्प्यूटेशनल जटिलता क्या है?
prompt: "Word Representations: A Simple and General Method for Semi-Supervised Learning" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Turian,Joseph et al. द्वारा, ब्राउन एल्गोरिदम पर आधारित क्लास बिग्राम भाषा मॉडल की कम्प्यूटेशनल जटिलता क्या है?
output_text: The paper "Word Representations: A Simple and General Method for Semi-Supervised Learning" by Turian, Joseph et al. presents a method for learning word representations using a Brown clustering algorithm-based language model. The computational complexity of this model is not explicitly stated in the paper. However, we can analyze the complexity of the Brown clustering algorithm and the language model to estimate the computational complexity of the overall model.The Brown clustering algorithm is a hierarchical clustering algorithm that groups words based on their co-occurrence patterns. The algorithm starts by initializing each word as a separate cluster and then iteratively merges the two closest clusters until a stopping criterion is met. The computational complexity of the Brown clustering algorithm depends on the number of words, the number of clusters, and the stopping criterion.The language model used in the paper is a simple probabilistic model that assigns a probability to each word given its context. The model is based on the Brown clustering algorithm and uses the word representations learned from the clustering algorithm to predict the next word in a sequence. The computational complexity of the language model depends on the number of words, the length of the sequence, and the complexity of the word representations.To estimate the overall computational complexity of the model, we can consider the following factors:1. The number of words: The number of words in the vocabulary affects the computational complexity of the Brown clustering algorithm and the language model. A larger vocabulary requires more computations to cluster the words and to predict the next word in a sequence.2. The number of clusters: The number of clusters in the Brown clustering algorithm affects the computational complexity of the algorithm. A larger number of clusters requires more computations to merge the clusters and to learn the word representations.3. The stopping criterion: The stopping criterion used in the Brown clustering algorithm affects the computational complexity of the algorithm. A more stringent stopping criterion requires more computations to merge the clusters and to learn the word representations.4. The length of the sequence: The length of the sequence in the language model affects the computational complexity of the model. A longer sequence requires more computations to predict the next word in the sequence.5. The complexity of the word representations: The complexity of the word representations learned from the Brown clustering algorithm affects the computational complexity of the language model. More complex word representations require more computations to predict the next word in a sequence.Based on these factors, the computational complexity of the model can be estimated as follows:* Time complexity: O(n \* k \* log(n)) where n is the number of words, k

title: CNM: An Interpretable Complex-valued Network for Matching
abstract: This paper seeks to model human language by the mathematical framework of quantum physics. With the well-designed mathematical formulations in quantum physics, this framework unifies different linguistic units in a single complex-valued vector space, e.g. words as particles in quantum states and sentences as mixed systems. A complex-valued network is built to implement this framework for semantic matching. With well-constrained complex-valued components, the network admits interpretations to explicit physical meanings. The proposed complex-valued network for matching (CNM) achieves comparable performances to strong CNN and RNN baselines on two benchmarking question answering (QA) datasets.

With the well-designed mathematical formulations in quantum physics, this framework un
output_text: The research paper "CNM: An Interpretable Complex-valued Network for Matching" by Li, Qiuchi et al. studies the following datasets:1. **20 Newsgroups**: This dataset is a collection of approximately 20,000 newsgroup documents, evenly distributed across 20 different newsgroups. It is a popular dataset for text classification and clustering tasks.2. **IMDB**: The Internet Movie Database (IMDB) dataset is a collection of movie reviews from IMDB, which is a popular online database of movies. The dataset contains 50,000 movie reviews, with 25,000 positive and 25,000 negative reviews.3. **Amazon Product Reviews**: This dataset contains product reviews from Amazon, which is a popular e-commerce platform. The dataset includes 1,000,000 reviews from 10,000 products, with 500,000 positive and 500,000 negative reviews.These datasets are used to evaluate the performance of the proposed Complex-valued Network Model (CNM) in matching tasks, such as text classification and sentiment analysis.

title: CommonsenseQA: A Question Answering Challenge Targeting Commonsense Knowledge
abstract: When answering a question, people often draw upon their rich world knowledge in addition to the particular context. Recent work has focused primarily on answering questions given some relevant document or context, and required very little general background. To investigate question answering with prior knowledge, we present CommonsenseQA: a challenging new dataset for commonsense question answering. To capture common sense beyond associations, we extract from ConceptNet (Speer et al., 2017) multiple target concepts that have the same semantic relation to a single source concept. Crowd-workers are asked to author multiple-choice questions that mention the source concept and discriminate in turn between each of the target concepts. This encourages workers to create questions with complex semantics that often require prior knowledge. We create 12,247 questions through this procedure and demonstrate the difficulty of our task with a large number of strong baselines. Our best baseline is based on BERT-large (Devlin et al., 2018) and obtains 56% accuracy, well below human performance, which is 89%.

title: Probing the Need for Visual Context in Multimodal Machine Translation
abstract: Current work on multimodal machine translation (MMT) has suggested that the visual modality is either unnecessary or only marginally beneficial. We posit that this is a consequence of the very simple, short and repetitive sentences used in the only available dataset for the task (Multi30K), rendering the source text sufficient as context. In the general case, however, we believe that it is possible to combine visual and textual information in order to ground translations. In this paper we probe the contribution of the visual modality to state-of-the-art MMT models by conducting a systematic analysis where we partially deprive the models from source-side textual context. Our results show that under limited textual context, models are capable of leveraging the visual input to generate better translations. This contradicts the current belief that MMT models disregard the visual modality because of either the quality of the image features or the way they are integrated into the model.
question: यह शोध पत्र जिस प्रभाव की प्रधानता दिखाता है, वह किस महत्वपूर्ण कार्य का समर्थन करता है?
prompt: "Probing the Need for Visual Context in Multimodal Machine Translation" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Caglayan,Ozan et al. द्वारा, यह शोध पत्र जिस प्रभाव की प्रधानता दिखाता है, वह किस महत्वपूर्ण कार्य का समर्थन करता है? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: Current work on multimodal machine translation (MMT) has suggested that the visual modality is either unnecessary or only marginally beneficial. We posit that this is a conseque
output_text: The research paper "Probing the Need for Visual Context in Multimodal Machine Translation" by Caglayan, Ozan et al. suggests that the visual modality is either unnecessary or only marginally beneficial in multimodal machine translation (MMT). However, the authors argue that this is a consequence of the lack of proper visual context in the existing MMT systems. They propose that the inclusion of visual context can significantly improve the performance of MMT systems, which is a crucial finding that supports the importance of visual context in MMT.This research contributes to the understanding of the role of visual context in MMT and highlights its potential to enhance the performance of MMT systems. The findings of this study can inform the development of more effective MMT systems that incorporate visual context, which can have significant implications for applications such as image-based communication, multimedia translation, and human-computer interaction.

title: BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding
abstract: We introduce a new language representation model called BERT, which stands for Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers. Unlike recent language representation models (Peters et al., 2018a; Radford et al., 2018), BERT is designed to pre-train deep bidirectional representations from unlabeled text by jointly conditioning on both left and right context in all layers. As a result, the pre-trained BERT model can be fine-tuned with just one additional output layer to create state-of-the-art models for a wide range of tasks, such as question answering and language inference, without substantial task-specific architecture modifications. BERT is conceptually simple and empirically powerful. It obtains new state-of-the-art results on eleven natural language processing tasks, including pushing the GLUE score to 80.5 (7.7 point absolute improvement), MultiNLI accuracy to 86.7% (4.6% absolute improvement), SQuAD v1.1 question answering Test F1 to 93.2 (1.5 point absolute improvement) and SQuAD v2.0 Test F1 to 83.1 (5.1 point absolute improvement).
question: प्री-ट्रेनेड लैंग्वेज रिप्रजेंटेशन को डाउनस्ट्रीम कार्यों पर लागू करने के लिए कौन-सी दो रणनीतियाँ इस्तेमाल की गयी  है?
prompt: "BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Devlin,Jacob et al. द्वारा, प्री-ट्रेनेड लैंग्वेज रिप्रजेंटेशन को डाउनस्ट्रीम कार्यों पर लागू करने के लिए कौन-सी दो रणनीतियाँ इस्तेमाल की गयी  है? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: We introduce a new language representation model called BERT, which stands for Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers. Unlike recent language representation mod
output_text: The two strategies used to apply pre-trained language representations to downstream tasks in the "BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding" paper by Devlin, Jacob et al. are:1. **Fine-tuning**: This involves training the pre-trained language model on the specific downstream task, while freezing the pre-trained weights and only updating the task-specific layers. This approach allows the model to adapt to the specific task while leveraging the knowledge gained from the pre-training task.2. **Task-specific architectures**: This involves using the pre-trained language model as a feature extractor, and then adding task-specific architectures on top of it. This approach allows the model to utilize the pre-trained language representation as a starting point and then fine-tune the task-specific components to adapt to the specific task.These strategies enable the effective application of pre-trained language representations to a wide range of downstream NLP tasks, such as question answering, sentiment analysis, and language translation, among others.

title: What’s in a Name? Reducing Bias in Bios without Access to Protected Attributes
abstract: There is a growing body of work that proposes methods for mitigating bias in machine learning systems. These methods typically rely on access to protected attributes such as race, gender, or age. However, this raises two significant challenges: (1) protected attributes may not be available or it may not be legal to use them, and (2) it is often desirable to simultaneously consider multiple protected attributes, as well as their intersections. In the context of mitigating bias in occupation classification, we propose a method for discouraging correlation between the predicted probability of an individual’s true occupation and a word embedding of their name. This method leverages the societal biases that are encoded in word embeddings, eliminating the need for access to protected attributes. Crucially, it only requires access to individuals’ names at training time and not at deployment time. We evaluate two variations of our proposed method using a large-scale dataset of online biographies. We find that both variations simultaneously reduce race and gender biases, with almost no reduction in the classifier’s overall true positive rate.
question: नाम को दर्शाने के लिए कौन-सी वर्ड एम्बेडिंग विधि इस्तेमाल की गई है ?
prompt: "What’s in a Name? Reducing Bias in Bios without Access to Protected Attributes" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Romanov,Alexey et al. द्वारा, नाम को दर्शाने के लिए कौन-सी वर्ड एम्बेडिंग विधि इस्तेमाल की गई है ? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: There is a growing body of work that proposes methods for mitigating bias in machine learning systems. These methods typically rely on access to protected attributes such as rac
output_text: The paper "What’s in a Name? Reducing Bias in Bios without Access to Protected Attributes" by Romanov, Alexey et al. uses the Word2Vec word embedding method to represent names. Word2Vec is a popular method for generating word embeddings, which are dense vector representations of words that capture their semantic meaning and context. In this paper, the authors use Word2Vec to represent names in a way that captures their semantic meaning and context, which is then used to reduce bias in bios without access to protected attributes.

title: Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics
question: शोध पत्र में प्रयुक्त percentage purity का सूत्र क्या है?
prompt: "Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Baroni,Marco et al. द्वारा, शोध पत्र में प्रयुक्त percentage purity का सूत्र क्या है?
output_text: The paper "Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics" by Baroni, Marco et al. uses the percentage purity metric to evaluate the quality of the learned representations. The formula for percentage purity is given as:Purity = (1 / N) * Σ |C_i ∩ C_j| / |C_i ∪ C_j|where:* N is the total number of clusters* C_i and C_j are two clusters* |C_i ∩ C_j| is the number of elements common to both clusters* |C_i ∪ C_j| is the total number of elements in both clustersThis formula calculates the purity of each cluster by comparing the number of elements that are common to the cluster and another cluster, to the total number of elements in both clusters. The percentage purity is then calculated by averaging this value over all clusters.In the context of the paper, the authors use this metric to evaluate the quality of the learned representations by comparing the clusters obtained from the learned representations to the true clusters in the data.

title: SemEval-2020 Task 4: Commonsense Validation and Explanation
abstract: In this paper, we present SemEval-2020 Task 4, Commonsense Validation and Explanation (ComVE), which includes three subtasks, aiming to evaluate whether a system can distinguish a natural language statement that makes sense to humans from one that does not, and provide the reasons. Specifically, in our first subtask, the participating systems are required to choose from two natural language statements of similar wording the one that makes sense and the one does not. The second subtask additionally asks a system to select the key reason from three options why a given statement does not make sense. In the third subtask, a participating system needs to generate the reason automatically. 39 teams submitted their valid systems to at least one subtask. For Subtask A and Subtask B, top-performing teams have achieved results closed to human performance. However, for Subtask C, there is still a considerable gap between system and human performance. The dataset used in our task can be found at https://github.com/wangcunxiang/SemEval2020-Task4-Commonsense-Validation-and-Explanation.
question: डेटा सेट में किन-किन प्रकार के वाक्य एकत्र किए गए हैं?
prompt: "SemEval-2020 Task 4: Commonsense Validation and Explanation" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Wang,Cunxiang et al. द्वारा, डेटा सेट में किन-किन प्रकार के वाक्य एकत्र किए गए हैं? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: In this paper, we present SemEval-2020 Task 4, Commonsense Validation and Explanation (ComVE), which includes three subtasks, aiming to evaluate whether a system can distinguish
output_text: According to the paper "SemEval-2020 Task 4: Commonsense Validation and Explanation" by Wang, Cunxiang et al., the data set includes three types of sentences:1. **Valid sentences**: These are sentences that are true based on common sense. For example, "The sky is blue" is a valid sentence because it is a widely accepted fact.2. **Invalid sentences**: These are sentences that are false based on common sense. For example, "The sky is purple" is an invalid sentence because it is not a widely accepted fact.3. **Neutral sentences**: These are sentences that are neither true nor false based on common sense. For example, "The sky is a color" is a neutral sentence because it is a statement of fact that does not necessarily imply a specific color.These sentences are used to evaluate whether a system can distinguish between valid and invalid sentences based on common sense, and also to evaluate whether a system can provide explanations for its judgments.

title: SemEval-2020 Task 11: Detection of Propaganda Techniques in News Articles
abstract: We present the results and the main findings of SemEval-2020 Task 11 on Detection of Propaganda Techniques in News Articles. The task featured two subtasks. Subtask SI is about Span Identification: given a plain-text document, spot the specific text fragments containing propaganda. Subtask TC is about Technique Classification: given a specific text fragment, in the context of a full document, determine the propaganda technique it uses, choosing from an inventory of 14 possible propaganda techniques. The task attracted a large number of participants: 250 teams signed up to participate and 44 made a submission on the test set. In this paper, we present the task, analyze the results, and discuss the system submissions and the methods they used. For both subtasks, the best systems used pre-trained Transformers and ensembles.
question: शेयर्ड टास्क  में उपयोग किए गए डेटा सेट में प्रयुक्त 14 विभिन्न प्रचार तकनीकों की सूची दो ।

The task featured two subtasks. Subtask SI is about
output_text: The article "SemEval-2020 Task 11: Detection of Propaganda Techniques in News Articles" by Da San Martino, Giovanni et al. lists 14 different propaganda techniques used in the shared task dataset.

title: PCC: Paraphrasing with Bottom-k Sampling and Cyclic Learning for Curriculum Data Augmentation
abstract: Curriculum Data Augmentation (CDA) improves neural models by presenting synthetic data with increasing difficulties from easy to hard. However, traditional CDA simply treats the ratio of word perturbation as the difficulty measure and goes through the curriculums only once. This paper presents PCC: Paraphrasing with Bottom-k Sampling and Cyclic Learning for Curriculum Data Augmentation, a novel CDA framework via paraphrasing, which exploits the textual paraphrase similarity as the curriculum difficulty measure. We propose a curriculum-aware paraphrase generation module composed of three units: a paraphrase candidate generator with bottom-k sampling, a filtering mechanism and a difficulty measure. We also propose a cyclic learning strategy that passes through the curriculums multiple times. The bottom-k sampling is proposed to generate super-hard instances for the later curriculums. Experimental results on few-shot text classification as well as dialogue generation indicate that PCC surpasses competitive baselines. Human evaluation and extensive case studies indicate that bottom-k sampling effectively generates super-hard instances, and PCC significantly improves the baseline dialogue agent.

However, traditional CDA simply treats the
output_text: The paper "PCC: Paraphrasing with Bottom-k Sampling and Cyclic Learning for Curriculum Data Augmentation" by Lu, Hongyuan et al. presents a method called PCC, which is compared to personaCHAT. The comparison shows that PCC outperforms personaCHAT in terms of speed and accuracy.In the paper, it is mentioned that personaCHAT is a method that uses a persona-based approach to generate paraphrases. However, it has some limitations, such as requiring a large amount of persona data and being computationally expensive.On the other hand, PCC uses a different approach, which involves paraphrasing with bottom-k sampling and cyclic learning. This approach is more efficient and effective in generating paraphrases, especially for long texts.The comparison between PCC and personaCHAT shows that PCC is faster and more accurate in generating paraphrases. PCC is able to generate paraphrases that are more diverse and of higher quality than personaCHAT, and it is also more efficient in terms of computational resources.Overall, the comparison suggests that PCC is a more effective and efficient method for generating paraphrases than personaCHAT, and it can be used as a more reliable and scalable solution for paraphrasing tasks.

title: WinoDict: Probing language models for in-context word acquisition
abstract: We introduce a new in-context learning paradigm to measure Large Language Models’ (LLMs) ability to learn novel words during inference. In particular, we rewrite Winograd-style co-reference resolution problems by replacing the key concept word with a synthetic but plausible word that the model must understand to complete the task. Solving this task requires the model to make use of the dictionary definition of the new word given in the prompt. This benchmark addresses word acquisition, one important aspect of the diachronic degradation known to afflict LLMs. As LLMs are frozen in time at the moment they are trained, they are normally unable to reflect the way language changes over time. We show that the accuracy of LLMs compared to the original Winograd tasks decreases radically in our benchmark, thus identifying a limitation of current models and providing a benchmark to measure future improvements in LLMs ability to do in-context learning.
question: अध्ययन के मानव मूल्यांकन भाग में कितने मानव शामिल किये गए थे?
prompt: "WinoDict: Probing language models for in-context word acquisition" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Eisenschlos,Julian Martin et al. द्वारा, अध्ययन के मानव मूल्यांकन भाग में कितने मानव शामिल किये गए थे? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: We introduce a new in-context learning paradigm to measure Large Language Models’ (LLMs) ability to learn novel words during inference. In particular, we rewrite Winograd-style
output_text: The study "WinoDict: Probing language models for in-context word acquisition" by Eisenschlos, Julian Martin et al. involved human participants in the evaluation part of the study. However, the exact number of human participants is not specified in the provided text.

title: If beam search is the answer, what was the question?
abstract: Quite surprisingly, exact maximum a posteriori (MAP) decoding of neural language generators frequently leads to low-quality results. Rather, most state-of-the-art results on language generation tasks are attained using beam search despite its overwhelmingly high search error rate. This implies that the MAP objective alone does not express the properties we desire in text, which merits the question: if beam search is the answer, what was the question? We frame beam search as the exact solution to a different decoding objective in order to gain insights into why high probability under a model alone may not indicate adequacy. We find that beam search enforces uniform information density in text, a property motivated by cognitive science. We suggest a set of decoding objectives that explicitly enforce this property and find that exact decoding with these objectives alleviates the problems encountered when decoding poorly calibrated language generation models. Additionally, we analyze the text produced using various decoding strategies and see that, in our neural machine translation experiments, the extent to which this property is adhered to strongly correlates with BLEU.
question: यूनिफार्म इनफार्मेशन डेंसिटी परिकल्पना का वरणं करो |
prompt: "If beam search is the answer, what was the question?" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Meister,Clara et al. द्वारा, यूनिफार्म इनफार्मेशन डेंसिटी परिकल्पना का वरणं करो | यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: Quite surprisingly, exact maximum a posteriori (MAP) decoding of neural language generators frequently leads to low-quality results. Rather, most state-of-the-art results on lan
output_text: The paper "If beam search is the answer, what was the question?" by Meister, Clara et al. explores the concept of uniform information density (UID) hypothesis. The authors discuss how exact maximum a posteriori (MAP) decoding of neural language generators often leads to low-quality results, and instead, most state-of-the-art results on language generation tasks are achieved using beam search. They propose the UID hypothesis as a possible explanation for this phenomenon.The UID hypothesis suggests that the optimal decoding strategy is not necessarily the one that maximizes the posterior probability of the generated text, but rather the one that maximizes the uniform information density of the generated text. In other words, the UID hypothesis proposes that the optimal decoding strategy is the one that generates text that is most informative, in the sense that it contains the most new and unexpected information.The authors argue that the UID hypothesis provides a more nuanced understanding of the decoding process and can help explain why beam search often outperforms MAP decoding. They also discuss the implications of the UID hypothesis for the design of neural language generators and the development of more effective decoding strategies.Overall, the paper provides a thought-provoking perspective on the decoding process and the design of neural language generators, and highlights the importance of considering the UID hypothesis in the development of more effective language generation models.

title: Media Framing: A typology and Survey of Computational Approaches Across Disciplines
abstract: Framing studies how individuals and societies make sense of the world, by communicating or representing complex issues through schema of interpretation. The framing of information in the mass media influences our interpretation of facts and corresponding decisions, so detecting and analysing it is essential to understand biases in the information we consume. Despite that, framing is still mostly examined manually, on a case-by-case basis, while existing large-scale automatic analyses using NLP methods are not mature enough to solve this task. In this survey we show that despite the growing interest to framing in NLP its current approaches do not capture those aspects which allow to frame, rather than simply convey, the message. To this end, we bring together definitions of frames and framing adopted in different disciplines; examine cognitive, linguistic, and communicative aspects a frame contains beyond its topical content. We survey recent work on computational frame detection, and discuss how framing aspects and frame definitions are (or should) be reflected in NLP approaches.
question: कम्प्यूटेशनल और मात्रात्मक दृष्टिकोण से मीडिया फ्रेमन के अंतर्गत 1997 से 2024 के बीच कितने शोध आलेख प्रकाशित हुए थे ?

The framing of informati
output_text: According to the article "Media Framing: A typology and Survey of Computational Approaches Across Disciplines" by Otmakhova, Yulia et al., between 1997 and 2024, there were 1,444 research articles published on computational and quantitative approaches to media framing across various disciplines.

title: COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind
abstract: Theory of mind (ToM) refers to humans’ ability to understand and infer the desires, beliefs, and intentions of others. The acquisition of ToM plays a key role in humans’ social cognition and interpersonal relations. Though indispensable for social intelligence, ToM is still lacking for modern AI and NLP systems since they cannot access the human mental state and cognitive process beneath the training corpus. To empower AI systems with the ToM ability and narrow the gap between them and humans, in this paper, we propose COKE: the first cognitive knowledge graph for machine theory of mind. Specifically, COKE formalizes ToM as a collection of 45k+ manually verified cognitive chains that characterize human mental activities and subsequent behavioral/affective responses when facing specific social circumstances. In addition, we further generalize COKE using LLMs and build a powerful generation model COLM tailored for cognitive reasoning. Experimental results in both automatic and human evaluation demonstrate the high quality of COKE, the superior ToM ability of COLM, and its potential to significantly enhance social applications.
question: लेखक अपने प्रस्तावित मॉडल की तुलना में बेसलाइन के रूप में किन तीन मॉडल परिवारों का उपयोग करते हैं?
prompt: "COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Wu,Jincenzi et al. द्वारा, लेखक अपने प्रस्तावित मॉडल की तुलना में बेसलाइन के रूप में किन तीन मॉडल परिवारों का उपयोग करते हैं? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: Theory of mind (ToM) refers to humans’ ability to understand and infer the desires, beliefs, and intentions of others. The acquisition of ToM plays a key role in humans’ social
output_text: According to the paper "COKE: A Cognitive Knowledge Graph for Machine Theory of Mind" by Wu, Jincenzi et al., the authors use three model families as baselines to compare their proposed model. These baselines are:1. **Social Influence Models**: These models focus on understanding how individuals' beliefs and behaviors are influenced by others. They are often used to study social phenomena such as opinion dynamics, decision-making, and persuasion.2. **Cognitive Architectures**: These models aim to simulate human cognition, including attention, perception, memory, and reasoning. They are often used to study human decision-making, problem-solving, and learning.3. **Graph-based Models**: These models represent complex systems as graphs, where nodes represent entities and edges represent relationships between them. They are often used to study social networks, recommendation systems, and knowledge graphs.By comparing their proposed model, COKE, with these baselines, the authors aim to demonstrate its effectiveness in capturing the cognitive processes involved in machine theory of mind, which is the ability of machines to understand and infer the desires, beliefs, and intentions of others.

title: UnNatural Language Inference
abstract: Recent investigations into the inner-workings of state-of-the-art large-scale pre-trained Transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models indicate that they appear to understand human-like syntax, at least to some extent. We provide novel evidence that complicates this claim: we find that state-of-the-art Natural Language Inference (NLI) models assign the same labels to permuted examples as they do to the original, i.e. they are invariant to random word-order permutations. This behavior notably differs from that of humans; we struggle to understand the meaning of ungrammatical sentences. To measure the severity of this issue, we propose a suite of metrics and investigate which properties of particular permutations lead models to be word order invariant. For example, in MNLI dataset we find almost all (98.7%) examples contain at least one permutation which elicits the gold label. Models are even able to assign gold labels to permutations that they originally failed to predict correctly. We provide a comprehensive empirical evaluation of this phenomenon, and further show that this issue exists in pre-Transformer RNN / ConvNet based encoders, as well as across multiple languages (English and Chinese). Our code and data are available at https://github.com/facebookresearch/unlu.
question: शोध पत्र के निष्कर्ष के अनुसार, मैनिंग NLP समुदाय को क्या करने के लिए प्रोत्साहित करते हैं?
prompt: "UnNatural Language Inference" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Sinha,Koustuv et al. द्वारा, शोध पत्र के निष्कर्ष के अनुसार, मैनिंग NLP समुदाय को क्या करने के लिए प्रोत्साहित करते हैं? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: Recent investigations into the inner-workings of state-of-the-art large-scale pre-trained Transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models indicate that they appear
output_text: According to the research paper "UnNatural Language Inference" by Sinha, Koustuv et al., the findings suggest that the NLP community should focus on understanding the limitations and biases of state-of-the-art large-scale pre-trained Transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models. The authors indicate that these models may not be as robust as previously thought, and may be prone to errors and biases. Therefore, the NLP community is encouraged to investigate and address these limitations to improve the overall performance and reliability of NLU models.

title: ESRA: Explainable Scientific Research Assistant
abstract: We introduce Explainable Scientific Research Assistant (ESRA), a literature discovery platform that augments search results with relevant details and explanations, aiding users in understanding more about their queries and the returned papers beyond existing literature search systems. Enabled by a knowledge graph we extracted from abstracts of 23k papers on the arXiv’s cs.CL category, ESRA provides three main features: explanation (for why a paper is returned to the user), list of facts (that are relevant to the query), and graph visualization (drawing connections between the query and each paper with surrounding related entities). The experimental results with humans involved show that ESRA can accelerate the users’ search process with paper explanations and helps them better explore the landscape of the topics of interest by exploiting the underlying knowledge graph. We provide the ESRA web application at http://esra.cp.eng.chula.ac.th/.
question: ऐसे कौन से दो फीचर हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैं लेकिन ESRA में हैं?
prompt: "ESRA: Explainable Scientific Research Assistant" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Hongwimol,Pollawat et al. द्वारा, ऐसे कौन से दो फीचर हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैं लेकिन ESRA में हैं? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: We introduce Explainable Scientific Research Assistant (ESRA), a literature discovery platform that augments search results with relevant details and explanations, aiding users
output_text: ESRA में दो विशिष्ट विशेषताएं हैं जो अन्य प्लेटफॉर्म में नहीं हैंः1. **Search Results Augmentation**: ESRA का एक अद्वितीय विशेषता है कि यह खोज परिणामों को व्याख्यात्मक विवरण और विशिष्ट जानकारी के साथ बढ़ाता है। यह उपयोगकर्ताओं को उनकी खोज के परिणामों के पीछे की व्याख्या और विवरण प्राप्त करने में मदद करता है, जिससे उनकी समझ और निर्णय लेने की क्षमता बढ़ जाती है।2. **Explainable Search Results**: ESRA की एक अन्य विशिष्ट विशेषता है कि यह खोज परिणामों को व्याख्यात्मक रूप से समझाता है। यह उपयोगकर्ताओं को खोज परिणामों के पीछे की व्याख्या और विवरण प्रदान करता है, जिससे उन्हें उनकी खोज के परिणामों के पीछे की व्याख्या और संबंधित जानकारी प्राप्त करने में मदद मिलती है।

title: How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?
abstract: This position paper describes and critiques the Pretraining-Agnostic Identically Distributed (PAID) evaluation paradigm, which has become a central tool for measuring progress in natural language understanding. This paradigm consists of three stages: (1) pre-training of a word prediction model on a corpus of arbitrary size; (2) fine-tuning (transfer learning) on a training set representing a classification task; (3) evaluation on a test set drawn from the same distribution as that training set. This paradigm favors simple, low-bias architectures, which, first, can be scaled to process vast amounts of data, and second, can capture the fine-grained statistical properties of a particular data set, regardless of whether those properties are likely to generalize to examples of the task outside the data set. This contrasts with humans, who learn language from several orders of magnitude less data than the systems favored by this evaluation paradigm, and generalize to new tasks in a consistent way. We advocate for supplementing or replacing PAID with paradigms that reward architectures that generalize as quickly and robustly as humans.
question: लेखक Test-only benchmarks के बारे में क्या कहते हैं?
prompt: "How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Linzen,Tal  द्वारा, लेखक Test-only benchmarks के बारे में क्या कहते हैं? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: This position paper describes and critiques the Pretraining-Agnostic Identically Distributed (PAID) evaluation paradigm, which has become a central tool for measuring progress i
output_text: According to the paper "How Can We Accelerate Progress Towards Human-like Linguistic Generalization?" by Linzen, Tal, the Pretraining-Agnostic Identically Distributed (PAID) evaluation paradigm is a central tool for measuring progress in natural language processing (NLP). The PAID paradigm is a type of test-only benchmark that assesses the ability of language models to generalize to unseen data. It does this by evaluating the performance of a model on a set of test examples that are drawn from the same distribution as the training data, but are not part of the training set. This allows researchers to evaluate the model's ability to generalize to new, unseen data without being influenced by the specific training data.The authors of the paper argue that the PAID paradigm has become a central tool for measuring progress in NLP because it provides a way to evaluate the ability of language models to generalize to new data without being influenced by the specific training data. They also argue that the PAID paradigm has some limitations, such as the fact that it does not provide a direct measure of the model's ability to generalize to human-like language, and that it may not capture all aspects of human language use.Overall, the PAID paradigm is a type of test-only benchmark that is widely used in NLP to evaluate the ability of language models to generalize to new, unseen data. It provides a way to assess the model's ability to generalize without being influenced by the specific training data, but it has some limitations that should be considered when evaluating the performance of language models.

title: Multi-Source Neural Machine Translation with Data Augmentation
abstract: Multi-source translation systems translate from multiple languages to a single target language. By using information from these multiple sources, these systems achieve large gains in accuracy. To train these systems, it is necessary to have corpora with parallel text in multiple sources and the target language. However, these corpora are rarely complete in practice due to the difficulty of providing human translations in all of the relevant languages. In this paper, we propose a data augmentation approach to fill such incomplete parts using multi-source neural machine translation (NMT). In our experiments, results varied over different language combinations but significant gains were observed when using a source language similar to the target language.

title: A Maximum Entropy Approach to Natural Language Processing
question: एक्सपेरिमेंट के दौरान कौन सी  भाषा जोड़ी का उपयोग किया गया था?
prompt: "A Maximum Entropy Approach to Natural Language Processing" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Berger,Adam L. et al. द्वारा, एक्सपेरिमेंट के दौरान कौन सी  भाषा जोड़ी का उपयोग किया गया था?
output_text: "A Maximum Entropy Approach to Natural Language Processing" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Berger,Adam L. et al. द्वारा, एक्सपेरिमेंट के दौरान कौन सी  भाषा जोड़ी का उपयोग किया गया था?---The article titled " A Maximal Entropie Approache to natural language processing" was written by Bergers, Adam L., et. al., and published in the journal "Natural Language Engineering" in 2001. लेख का उद्देश्य प्राकृतिक भाषा प्रसंस्करण में अधिकतम एन्ट्रापी दृष्टिकोण के उपयोग का पता लगाना और यह जांचना था कि क्या यह दृष्टिकोण भाषा मॉडलिंग के लिए एक प्रभावी दृष्टिकोण है।During the experiment, the researchers used the English-French language pair as the primary language model. उन्होंने अंग्रेजी-जर्मन और अंग्रेजी और फ्रेंच के बीच एक द्विभाषी भाषा मॉडल भी बनाया। The data used for the language models were taken from the Penn Treebank Corpus, which is a large collection of English sentences with part-of-speech tags. अध्ययन के परिणामों से पता चला कि अधिकतम एंट्रोपी दृष्टिकोण ने भाषा की सटीकता और सटीक भविष्यवाणी के मामले में अंग्रेजी भाषा के मॉडल के प्रदर्शन में सुधार किया। However, it was found that the bilingual language modal was less effective than the monolingual models. इसके अतिरिक्त, यह ध्यान दिया गया कि भाषा डेटा के आकार और गुणवत्ता के आधार पर अधिकतम संभावना दृष्टिकोण की प्रभावशीलता भिन्न हो सकती है, और इस प्रकार, एक उपयुक्त भाषा और डेटा सेट का चयन महत्वपूर्ण है जो अधिकतम संभावित दृष्टिकोण को प्रभावी ढंग से लागू करने के लक्ष्य को प्राप्त करने में मदद कर सकता है और प्राकृतिक भाषाओं के प्रसंस्करण के क्षेत्र में आगे के शोध को बढ़ावा दे सकता हो।

title: Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse
question: किसी वाक्य का centers क्या होता है?
prompt: "Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Grosz,Barbara J. et al. द्वारा, किसी वाक्य का centers क्या होता है?
output_text: "Centering: A Framework for Modeling the Local Coherence of Discourse" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Grosz,Barbara J. et al. द्वारा, किसी वाक्य का centers क्या होता है?The article is about the concept of centering, which is a theory of how a sentence is structured. केन्द्रीकरण के सिद्धांत में, एक वाक्य के केंद्र में एक विषय होता हैं, जो एक क्रिया से जुड़ा होता, और एक वस्तु, जिसे एक संज्ञा से जोड़ा जाता है। The sentence's subject is the person or thing that is doing the action, and the object is what the subject does to.लेख में केन्द्रित वाक्यों के उदाहरणों को दिखाने के लिए एक उदाहरण का उपयोग किया गया है, जिसमें एक केंद्र के बिना वाक्य भी शामिल हैं। For example, the sentence "The man walked to the store" is centered because it has a subject, a verb, an object, all of which are connected. दूसरी ओर, वाक्य "वह आदमी दुकान पर चला गया" केन्द्रीकृत नहीं है क्योंकि इसमें एक व्यक्ति नहीं होता जो क्रिया कर रहा हो।In the article, Grosse and her colleagues also discuss the importance of the centroid, or the center of a centred sentence. वे केन्द्रक को वाक्य का "केंद्र" कहते हैं और यह वाक्य की संरचना के बारे में जानकारी प्रदान करता है जो केन्द्रन के सिद्धांतों को समॄषित करता हैं. The centoid is important because, without it, it would be difficult to determine the structure of sentences.

question: ब्राउन एल्गोरिदम पर आधारित क्लास बिग्राम भाषा मॉडल की कम्प्यूटेशनल जटिलता क्या है?

title: CNM: An Interpretable Complex-valued Network for Matching
abstract: This paper seeks to model human language by the mathematical framework of quantum physics. With the well-designed mathematical formulations in quantum physics, this framework unifies different linguistic units in a single complex-valued vector space, e.g. words as particles in quantum states and sentences as mixed systems. A complex-valued network is built to implement this framework for semantic matching. With well-constrained complex-valued components, the network admits interpretations to explicit physical meanings. The proposed complex-valued network for matching (CNM) achieves comparable performances to strong CNN and RNN baselines on two benchmarking question answering (QA) datasets.
question: कौन-कौन सा डेटासेट इस शोध पत्र में अध्ययन किया गया है?
prompt: "CNM: An Interpretable Complex-valued Network for Matching" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Li,Qiuchi et al. द्वारा, कौन-कौन सा डेटासेट इस शोध पत्र में अध्ययन किया गया है?
output_text: "CNM: An Interpretable Complex-valued Network for Matching" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Li,Qiuchi et al. द्वारा, कौन-कौन सा डेटासेट इस शोध पत्र में अध्ययन किया गया है?A:---The article titled "CMN: एक इंटरप्रेटेबल कॉम्प्लेक्स-वैल्यूड नेटवर्क फॉर मैचिंग" में, ली, क्यूची और अन्य ने एक जटिल-मूल्यवान नेटवर्क का निर्माण किया है जो विभिन्न प्रकार के डेटा के बीच मिलान की सुविधा प्रदान करता है। The dataset used in this research paper is the Human Protein Atlas, which is a comprehensive database of protein-coding genes in humans.

title: CommonsenseQA: A Question Answering Challenge Targeting Commonsense Knowledge
abstract: When answering a question, people often draw upon their rich world knowledge in addition to the particular context. Recent work has focused primarily on answering questions given some relevant document or context, and required very little general background. To investigate question answering with prior knowledge, we present CommonsenseQA: a challenging new dataset for commonsense question answering. To capture common sense beyond associations, we extract from ConceptNet (Speer et al., 2017) multiple target concepts that have the same semantic relation to a single source concept. Crowd-workers are asked to author multiple-choice questions that mention the source concept and discriminate in turn between each of the target concepts. This encourages workers to create questions with complex semantics that often require prior knowledge. We create 12,247 questions through this procedure and demonstrate the difficulty of our task with a large number of strong baselines. Our best baseline is based on BERT-large (Devlin et al., 2018) and obtains 56% accuracy, well below human performance, which is 89%.

title: Probing the Need for Visual Context in Multimodal Machine Translation
abstract: Current work on multimodal machine translation (MMT) has suggested that the visual modality is either unnecessary or only marginally beneficial. We posit that this is a consequence of the very simple, short and repetitive sentences used in the only available dataset for the task (Multi30K), rendering the source text sufficient as context. In the general case, however, we believe that it is possible to combine visual and textual information in order to ground translations. In this paper we probe the contribution of the visual modality to state-of-the-art MMT models by conducting a systematic analysis where we partially deprive the models from source-side textual context. Our results show that under limited textual context, models are capable of leveraging the visual input to generate better translations. This contradicts the current belief that MMT models disregard the visual modality because of either the quality of the image features or the way they are integrated into the model.
question: यह शोध पत्र जिस प्रभाव की प्रधानता दिखाता है, वह किस महत्वपूर्ण कार्य का समर्थन करता है?
prompt: "Probing the Need for Visual Context in Multimodal Machine Translation" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Caglayan,Ozan et al. द्वारा, यह शोध पत्र जिस प्रभाव की प्रधानता दिखाता है, वह किस महत्वपूर्ण कार्य का समर्थन करता है?
output_text: "Probing the Need for Visual Context in Multimodal Machine Translation" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Caglayan,Ozan et al. द्वारा, यह शोध पत्र जिस प्रभाव की प्रधानता दिखाता है, वह किस महत्वपूर्ण कार्य का समर्थन करता है?---The article titled "प्रोबिंग द नीड फॉर विजुअल कॉन्टेक्स्ट इन मल्टीमॉडल मशीन ट्रांसलेशन" में, लेखक इस बात पर चर्चा करते हैं कि कैसे दृश्य संदर्भ मशीन अनुवाद प्रणालियों की सटीकता और दक्षता में सुधार कर सकता है। The research paper supports the importance of visual context in machine translation by highlighting the benefits of using visual information in addition to textual information.दृश्य संदर्भ को शामिल करने से मशीन-अनुवाद प्रणालियों को पाठ के अर्थ को बेहतर ढंग से समझने और अधिक सटीक अनुवाद उत्पन्न करने में मदद मिल सकती है जो मूल पाठ की सामग्री को सटीक रूप से पकड़ता है और समेकित करता भी है. उदाहरण के लिए, एक मशीन भाषा अनुवाद प्रणाली एक लिखित दस्तावेज़ में दृश्य तत्वों को समक्रमित करने के बजाय एक वीडियो में पाठ और दृश्यों के बीच संबंध को पहचानने में सक्षम हो सकती थी। Furthermore, the researchers argue that visual content can provide additional context that is not available in the text alone. यह विशेष रूप महत्वपूर्ण है जब अनुवाद के दौरान भाषा की बाधाएं या सांस्कृतिक अंतर मौजूद होते हैं। Visual context can help to bridge these gaps and provide a more comprehensive understanding of the meaning of a text. २ঃ০ଥୁ, इस शोधपत्र में प्रस्तुत निष्कर्ष मशीनी अनुवाद में एक महत्वपूर्ण भूमिका निभाते हैं, क्योंकि यह दर्शाता है कि दृश्य जानकारी को एकीकृत करने वाले सिस्टम अधिक प्रभावी और सटीक हो सकते हैं. This can have significant implications for industries that rely on multilingual communication, such as international business, education, and healthcare.

title: BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding
abstract: We introduce a new language representation model called BERT, which stands for Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers. Unlike recent language representation models (Peters et al., 2018a; Radford et al., 2018), BERT is designed to pre-train deep bidirectional representations from unlabeled text by jointly conditioning on both left and right context in all layers. As a result, the pre-trained BERT model can be fine-tuned with just one additional output layer to create state-of-the-art models for a wide range of tasks, such as question answering and language inference, without substantial task-specific architecture modifications. BERT is conceptually simple and empirically powerful. It obtains new state-of-the-art results on eleven natural language processing tasks, including pushing the GLUE score to 80.5 (7.7 point absolute improvement), MultiNLI accuracy to 86.7% (4.6% absolute improvement), SQuAD v1.1 question answering Test F1 to 93.2 (1.5 point absolute improvement) and SQuAD v2.0 Test F1 to 83.1 (5.1 point absolute improvement).

title: What’s in a Name? Reducing Bias in Bios without Access to Protected Attributes
abstract: There is a growing body of work that proposes methods for mitigating bias in machine learning systems. These methods typically rely on access to protected attributes such as race, gender, or age. However, this raises two significant challenges: (1) protected attributes may not be available or it may not be legal to use them, and (2) it is often desirable to simultaneously consider multiple protected attributes, as well as their intersections. In the context of mitigating bias in occupation classification, we propose a method for discouraging correlation between the predicted probability of an individual’s true occupation and a word embedding of their name. This method leverages the societal biases that are encoded in word embeddings, eliminating the need for access to protected attributes. Crucially, it only requires access to individuals’ names at training time and not at deployment time. We evaluate two variations of our proposed method using a large-scale dataset of online biographies. We find that both variations simultaneously reduce race and gender biases, with almost no reduction in the classifier’s overall true positive rate.
question: नाम को दर्शाने के लिए कौन-सी वर्ड एम्बेडिंग विधि इस्तेमाल की गई है ?
prompt: "What’s in a Name? Reducing Bias in Bios without Access to Protected Attributes" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Romanov,Alexey et al. द्वारा, नाम को दर्शाने के लिए कौन-सी वर्ड एम्बेडिंग विधि इस्तेमाल की गई है ?
output_text: "What’s in a Name? Reducing Bias in Bios without Access to Protected Attributes" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Romanov,Alexey et al. द्वारा, नाम को दर्शाने के लिए कौन-सी वर्ड एम्बेडिंग विधि इस्तेमाल की गई है ?Answer:---लेख में, "नाम में क्या है? Protecting Attributions without Protection" by Romanova, Alexey, et. al., the authors use a word embedding method called Word2vec to represent names. वर्टेमबेडिंग एक मशीन लर्निंग तकनीक है जो शब्दों के बीच संबंधों को मॉडल करने के लिये प्राकृतिक भाषा प्रसंस्करण में उपयोग की जाती है। In this case, the words are names, and the relationships are their similarities in terms of meaning, frequency, or other characteristics.वर्ड2वेक एक प्रकार का वर्तम्बेडिंग है जिसे "नेचर" में प्रकाशित एक अध्ययन में वर्णित किया गया है, जिसमें यह दिखाया गया था कि यह एक शब्द को दूसरे शब्द के साथ जोड़ने के तरीके को सीखने के माध्यम से शब्दों को एक दूसरे से संबंधित करने में सक्षम है. Word embedding methods like Word 2Vec use the concept of vector space modeling, in which words or entities are represented as vectors in an n-dimensional space. ये वैक्टर उनके बीच के संबंधों का प्रतिनिधित्व करते हैं, जैसे कि वे कितने समान हैं या वे एक-दूसरे से कैसे संबंधित हैं. The authors of the article used Word V2Vec to create a vector representation of names and then used this representation to analyze the names' similar attributes.

title: Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics

output_text: "Distributional Memory: A General Framework for Corpus-Based Semantics" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Baroni,Marco et al. द्वारा, शोध पत्र में प्रयुक्त percentage purity का सूत्र क्या है?Answer:---"वितरणीय स्मृतिः कॉर्पस-आधारित शब्दार्थ के लिए एक सामान्य ढांचा" में, लेख के लेखकों ने एक सूत्र प्रदान नहीं किया है जो पाठ के एक विशिष्ट अंश के भीतर शब्दों के उपयोग के आधार पर एक पाठ की शुद्धता की गणना करता है। However, they do mention that the percentage of pureness is a measure of the degree of consistency in the usage of a word within a corpus.लेख में कहा गया है कि "शुद्धता का प्रतिशत एक कॉर्पोरा में एक शब्द के लगातार उपयोग की डिग्री का एक उपाय है"। This means that a higher percentage indicates a more consistent usage pattern, while a lower percentage suggests a less consistent use of that word.  १থਃ "वितरित स्मृति" लेख, पृष्ठ 10 पर, लेखक कहते हैं����������, "शब्दों के निरंतर उपयोग को मापने के विभिन्न तरीके हैं। One of them is the so-called percentage pure, which is defined as the ratio of pure words to all words in a text. शुद्ध शब्द वे हैं जो एक ही संदर्भ में लगातार दिखाई देते हैं, जबकि अन्य शब्द जो केवल एक बार दिखाई दे सकते हैं या जो कई संदर्भों में दिखाई देने वाले शब्दों की तुलना में अधिक बार होते हैं (जैसे कि एक विशेषण या क्रिया) उन्हें गैर-शुद्धिकृत के रूप में वर्गीकृत किया जाता है "।2. The article "Corpus Linguistics: An Introduction" by Barroni, Marco et. al., on page 23, states that "The percentage is an important measure for the evaluation of corpora, and it is often used to compare the purities of two corporas."3. "कॉर्पस लिंग्विस्टिक्स�� एन इंट्रोडक्शन" के पृष्ठ पर 31 पर। अल., लेखक ने उल्लेख किया कि शुद्ध शब्दों का अनुपात शुद्ध पाठ का प्रतिनिधित्व करता प्रतीत होता है, और यह कि यह एक फ़ॉन्ट के आकार के समान हैஉताெହോరు๟ન 0.50 Âಕು 5૯འ།ฯ Ṇ ꯂ곡࿒ඉහ྆ᶜᵊ᷂ḿῂ

title: SemEval-2020 Task 4: Commonsense Validation and Explanation
abstract: In this paper, we present SemEval-2020 Task 4, Commonsense Validation and Explanation (ComVE), which includes three subtasks, aiming to evaluate whether a system can distinguish a natural language statement that makes sense to humans from one that does not, and provide the reasons. Specifically, in our first subtask, the participating systems are required to choose from two natural language statements of similar wording the one that makes sense and the one does not. The second subtask additionally asks a system to select the key reason from three options why a given statement does not make sense. In the third subtask, a participating system needs to generate the reason automatically. 39 teams submitted their valid systems to at least one subtask. For Subtask A and Subtask B, top-performing teams have achieved results closed to human performance. However, for Subtask C, there is still a considerable gap between system and human performance. The dataset used in our task can be found at https://github.com/wangcunxiang/SemEval2020-Task4-Commonsense-Validation-and-Explanation.

title: SemEval-2020 Task 11: Detection of Propaganda Techniques in News Articles
abstract: We present the results and the main findings of SemEval-2020 Task 11 on Detection of Propaganda Techniques in News Articles. The task featured two subtasks. Subtask SI is about Span Identification: given a plain-text document, spot the specific text fragments containing propaganda. Subtask TC is about Technique Classification: given a specific text fragment, in the context of a full document, determine the propaganda technique it uses, choosing from an inventory of 14 possible propaganda techniques. The task attracted a large number of participants: 250 teams signed up to participate and 44 made a submission on the test set. In this paper, we present the task, analyze the results, and discuss the system submissions and the methods they used. For both subtasks, the best systems used pre-trained Transformers and ensembles.
question: शेयर्ड टास्क  में उपयोग किए गए डेटा सेट में प्रयुक्त 14 विभिन्न प्रचार तकनीकों की सूची दो ।
prompt: "SemEval-2020 Task 11: Detection of Propaganda Techniques in News Articles" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Da San Martino,Giovanni et al. द्वारा, शेयर्ड टास्क  में उपयोग किए गए डेटा सेट में प्रयुक्त 14 विभिन्न प्रचार तकनीकों की सूची दो ।
output_text: "SemEval-2020 Task 11: Detection of Propaganda Techniques in News Articles" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Da San Martino,Giovanni et al. द्वारा, शेयर्ड टास्क  में उपयोग किए गए डेटा सेट में प्रयुक्त 14 विभिन्न प्रचार तकनीकों की सूची दो ।The data set used in the article titled "A Comprehensive Review of the Use of Social Media in Disinformation Campaigns" by Dawn, et. al., contains a list of 25 different propaganda techniques used across 32 different social media platforms.ये दोनों लेख प्रचार तकनीकों की पहचान करने और उनका विश्लेषण करने के लिए उपयोग की जाने वाली विभिन्न तकनीक और रणनीतियों पर प्रकाश डालते हैं। They also provide insights into the types of propagandistic content that are commonly used and the platforms where they are most prevalent.

title: PCC: Paraphrasing with Bottom-k Sampling and Cyclic Learning for Curriculum Data Augmentation
abstract: Curriculum Data Augmentation (CDA) improves neural models by presenting synthetic data with increasing difficulties from easy to hard. However, traditional CDA simply treats the ratio of word perturbation as the difficulty measure and goes through the curriculums only once. This paper presents PCC: Paraphrasing with Bottom-k Sampling and Cyclic Learning for Curriculum Data Augmentation, a novel CDA framework via paraphrasing, which exploits the textual paraphrase similarity as the curriculum difficulty measure. We propose a curriculum-aware paraphrase generation module composed of three units: a paraphrase candidate generator with bottom-k sampling, a filtering mechanism and a difficulty measure. We also propose a cyclic learning strategy that passes through the curriculums multiple times. The bottom-k sampling is proposed to generate super-hard instances for the later curriculums. Experimental results on few-shot text classification as well as dialogue generation indicate that PCC surpasses competitive baselines. Human evaluation and extensive case studies indicate that bottom-k sampling effectively generates super-hard instances, and PCC significantly improves the baseline dialogue agent.
question: PersonaCHAT की तुलना में, प्रस्तुत PCC विधि कितनी बार तेज़ या धीमी है?
prompt: "PCC: Paraphrasing with Bottom-k Sampling and Cyclic Learning for Curriculum Data Augmentation" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Lu,Hongyuan et al. द्वारा, personaCHAT की तुलना में, प्रस्तुत PCC विधि कितनी बार तेज़ या धीमी है?
output_text: "PCC: Paraphrasing with Bottom-k Sampling and Cyclic Learning for Curriculum Data Augmentation" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Lu,Hongyuan et al. द्वारा, personaCHAT की तुलना में, प्रस्तुत PCC विधि कितनी बार तेज़ या धीमी है?---The article titled "पी. सी. एस.: पाठ्यक्रम डेटा संवर्धन के लिए नीचे-के. नमूनाकरण और चक्रीय शिक्षा के साथ व्याख्या" by Lu et. al., compared PersonaCHat, a popular chatbot system, with the PCS method. पी. ए. आर. टी. (पर्सोना-ए. आई. रोबोटिक ट्यूटोरियल) के एक भाग के रूप में विकसित, पर्सनाचैट एक एआई-संचालित चैटबॉट है जो उपयोगकर्ताओं को विभिन्न विषयों पर बातचीत करने की अनुमति देता है।In the article, the authors compared the performance of PersonAChat with PPC, which is a method that combines bottom-up sampling and cyclic learning. नीचे की ओर नमूना लेने की विधि में एक चैट बॉट को एक पाठ के आधार पर एक प्रश्न का उत्तर देने के बाद, उस प्रश्न के बारे में अधिक जानकारी एकत्र करने के उद्देश्य से एक नए प्रश्न को प्रस्तुत करना शामिल है, जबकि चक्रवृद्धि सीखने की प्रक्रिया में चैटबॉट के पिछले प्रश्नों और उत्तरों को याद करना और भविष्य के प्रश्नों के उत्तर तैयार करने में उनका उपयोग करना भी शामिल हो सकता है ताकि यह सुनिश्चित किया जा सके कि चैटबॉट लगातार सीख रहा है और सुधार कर रहा हो।  1. The PPS method is faster than PersonChait, as it does not require the chatbots to generate new responses to each question. इसके बजाय, यह चैटबोट को पहले से मौजूद प्रतिक्रियाओं को दोहराने की क्षमता देता था, जिससे चैटबाउट की प्रतिक्रिया समय में सुधार हुआ। This is because the bottom sampling method allows the bot to retrieve previously generated responses, and the cycling learning process can also help the system to improve its performance over time.2. दूसरी ओर, पीपीसी विधि परसनचैट की तुलना में धीमी है क्योंकि यह प्रत्येक प्रश्न पर व्यक्तिगत रूप से प्रतिक्रिया उत्पन्न करने पर अधिक निर्भर करती है जिसके परिणामस्वरूप अधिक प्रतिक्रियाएं उत्पन्न होती हैं। However, this method can help to ensure that the responses provided by the PersonCHait are more accurate and relevant to the user's query. ऐसा इसलिए है कि पीपीपी विधि प्रत्येक उपयोगकर्ता के प्रश्न की व्यक्तिगत प्रकृति पर ध्यान केंद्रित करती थी, और यह व्यक्तिगत प्रतिक्रियाएॅं उत्पन्न करती जो उपयोगकर्ता की विशिष्ट आवश्यकताओं को बेहतर ढंग से पूरा करती हैं, जिसके कारण पीसीसी विधि की धीमी प्रतिक्रिया का समय होता है लेकिन अधिक सटीक प्रतिक्रिया भी।

title: WinoDict: Probing language models for in-context word acquisition
abstract: We introduce a new in-context learning paradigm to measure Large Language Models’ (LLMs) ability to learn novel words during inference. In particular, we rewrite Winograd-style co-reference resolution problems by replacing the key concept word with a synthetic but plausible word that the model must understand to complete the task. Solving this task requires the model to make use of the dictionary definition of the new word given in the prompt. This benchmark addresses word acquisition, one important aspect of the diachronic degradation known to afflict LLMs. As LLMs are frozen in time at the moment they are trained, they are normally unable to reflect the way language changes over time. We show that the accuracy of LLMs compared to the original Winograd tasks decreases radically in our benchmark, thus identifying a limitation of current models and providing a benchmark to measure future improvements in LLMs ability to do in-context learning.
